DIV1.P: BY THOMAS WRIGHT, ESQ., M. A., F. S. A., HON. M. R. S. L.
EDITED AND COLLATED BY RICHARD PAUL WÜLCKER.

DIV2.HEAD: XIII. SEMI-SAXON VOCABULARY. The vocabulary given above, which appears from the decadence of the gram∣matical forms, and from the orthography, to belong to about the middle of the twelfth century, is an abridgement of Nr. X. It was discovered, in the fragment∣ary form in which it is here printed, on some leaves of vellum used as the cover or binding of one of the old registers of Worcester Cathedral, by Sir Thomas Phil∣lipps, who printed a few copies privately. It there followed a copy of Alfric's Gram∣mar, written in the same language, and is an extremely curious monument of this latter in its state of transition. It has been carefully corrected in the present edition. (OF THE TWELFTH CENTURY.)

Uulgus, cheorlfolc. Cf. pag. 309 l. 39. R. W.

Cliens, uel clientulus, inkniht. The leaves of the MS. had been cut at the top and bottom, when they were used to form the cover of a book, which caused the lacunae indicated by these breaks. The lesser deflciencies are the result of mutilations of the edges of the leaves.

DIV2.HEAD: XIV. VOCABULARY OF THE NAMES OF PLANTS. This vocabulary of names of plants, evidently intended for the use of a medic∣al practitioner, is preserved in a manu∣script in the British Museum (MS. Harl. No. 978, fol. 24, vo), which appears to have been written in the period interven∣ing between the battles of Lewes and Evesham, that is, in 1264 or 1265. The explanations of the Latin names are given in Anglo-Norman and in English; and in a few instances either the Anglo-Norman or English is omitted, and even in one or two cases the Latin. It is given here as illustrating the lists of plants in the other vocabularies in the present volume. The history of the popular nomenclature of plants is a very curious and interesting subject; and the manuscripts of all periods are very rich in materials for it. There is another list of names of plants in the three languages, resembling the one here printed, but arranged in alphabetical order, and rather more full, in a manuscript of the fourteenth century in the British Mu∣seum, MS. Sloane, No. 5. (OF THE MIDDLE OF THE THIRTEENTH CENTURY.)

DIV2.HEAD: XV. A LATIN AND ENGLISH VOCABULARY. (OF THE FIFTEENTH CENTURY. This vocabulary is preserved in a manuscript in the Library of the Trinity College, Cambridge. The MS. is of the 15th century. Our text is based on a copy made by Mr. W. Aldis Wright.)

LIST.ITEM: Abecula, le ance the bake of a knyf.
Abestis intestina hostiarum aspiciens, et ance a gyller of bestys.
Abhinc in antea, ance fro hen forth ward.
Ablacto . i. a lacte remouere, ance to awenye.
Ac eciam ance and also. vel and forsothe.
Acopa . . . ance an obligacion or a tayl.
Acra . . . ance an aker of lond.
Acroceramen . . . ance a wawe of the see.
Acticola . . . ance Ramsyn. In the margin.
Adagonista, ance a man of lawe.
Adhereo, to drawe or to cleuy to.
Adunco, ance to drawe wyth an hooke.
Alaris, ance a company of hors.
Alicitor, ance an hobeye et hic Pere∣grinus idem est.
Alpinus, ance longend to hylle of alpys.
Alterutrum, ance fro on tyl an othyr.
Amfora uel amphora, ance a tankard.
Amphibulus, ance a sclauayn or fal∣dyng.

Aquagium, ance a gutur or a condyt.
Aquebaiulus, ance an holy water clerk.
Arano to flowe to reme as water & make fayre.
Arculus, ance the Arsyon of a sad∣elle.

Aspersorium, ance an holy water stykke.
Attractorium, ance a trayne, sed me∣lius a trays.
Attat interiectio timentis ut expaves∣centis, ance for dowte.
Attenuo, to make thynne or feble.
Attollo, ance to lyft up, or to do a way.
Auccionator et Auccionatrix, an huk∣ker & an hukkester.

Baffa, ance a flycche of bacon.

Barbillus, ance a ruget vel melius a barbyle.

Birrus vel Birrum, i. grossum vesti∣mentum, ance a dudde.
Bombinco, to crye as a bee.

Capisterium, ance a vanne [or a Seve.]
Cappa, ance the cappe of a fleyle.

Cardo, ance a thystell, or a tesell.
Carniprivium, ance shrofday, quia tunc privamur carnibus.
Catello, to mewe or to tykele.
Celatorium, ance a celour, or a co∣verlyt.

Petulus, -la, -lum, ance whyt foted et dicitur de equo.
Pictacio, -as, ance to puynte, or to clovte.
Pictaciarius, ance a Cobulare, or a Cloutere.
Pindo, ance a baker, or a kneder.
Piperis mola, ance a Pyper querne.
Pisto, ance to knede or bake.
Pistrio, ance to moolde or bake.
Pistrio, ance a moolder or a bakere.
Planatorium, ance a boture, instru∣mentum ferrarij est.
Planicies, ance Playn et etiam in panno ance dicitur Champe.
Plostrum, ance a chare of ij whelys.
Plumacius, ance a plumere avis est.
Plumbatum, ance a coope of leed.
Plumbilamina, ance a plate of leed.
Polimitus, Ray or motle or medlee.
Posse, ance a lytyl hauynge, or a lytyl myght.
Postsellium, ance the hyndur assyoun of a sadyl.
Prefero, ance to bere by fore.
Prepositor, ance a setter of mes.
Presellum, ance the assyon of a sa∣delle.
Presumo, ance to take on honde, or awntur.
Pretendo, ance to go by fore.
Prevaleo, ance to be myghty, or more worthe.
Prevenio, ance to come by fore.
Proditor, ance a traytour, or a tur∣mentour.
Proreto, ance to sterne or to stere out.
Prosectum, ance a Jeblet of the goos.
Prossus, ance owterly, sed melius prorsus.
Provideo, ance to purveye, or to see byfore.
Provoco, ance to tourne & to calle out.
Proximo, ance to make next, or ny.
Pula, ance medlyng of water and wyne.
Pullificio, to hacche chykyn, to make derke.
Pupilla, ance the appul of the ye.
Putacio, to poynte, or to cloute.
Quia et quoniam, ance for why.
Rapax, ance a rauenere, or Rauasch∣ynge.
Recano, to crye as a tygre.

ITEM.HI: Recinum vel Recinium, matronale ope∣rimentum sive quedam vestis vel pallium quod vulgo dicitur Movortem vel quoddam rete.

LIST.ITEM: Recreo, ance to fylle or aye make.
Requiesco, ance to bygynne to rest.
Resero, ance to vnluke, or to shewe.
Reticulum, a calle. Item reticulum, a rayle [vel a rayne.]
Rocus, homo scacci, ance a Roke.
Rubella, ance a ruget, piscis est.
Rugella, i. rubella, ance a ruget.
Ruga, [ance a wrynkyl, or a playt.]
Ruscus, ance a grost, or furses.
Salpo, i. cornubium, ance an horn∣pype.
Sambuca, ance eldertre. Item sam∣buca est quoddam genus simphonie musicum, ance a Gytterne.
Sarabarra, sunt fluxa et sinuosa vestimenta, vel capitum tegmina, vel ance a sclauayn.
Sarrio, ance to clene, cutte or wede.
Sarissa, ance a materas, et quoddam genus armorum, ance a Jakke of defense.
Scrabo, -bonis, hic, i. vespe longiora crura habentes. Item invenitur Cra∣bo, -bonis et scabo, ance a dore.
Scaccus, ance the meny of the cheker.
Scalprum, ance a grate, or a shaue.
Scansile, ance a styrop et ance a style.
Scarabo, ance a scharabot [et ance a bytylle.]
Scarifactor et Scarifactrix, ance a gratere.
Scelero et sceleror, ance to do felanye.
Scindula, ance a shyngul. Item ance a blad.
Scipio, ance a maner of an hokedstaf.
Sclavina, est vestis peregrinorum, ance a Sclauayne.
Scon, interjectio, ance showe, ut di∣citur gallina lirida scon, ance py∣keled hen show.
Scorpio, quoddam animal venenosum. Item dicitur quidam piscis vel ver∣mis, ance a stykelyng.
Scrinium, vas vel locus ubi libri vel thesauri servantur. Item ance a Screne.
Scruta, exta i. tripe, ance the felvelde.
Semicinctorium, ance a synk or a lace.
Semoveo, ance to do a wey.
Sicca, quidam piscis est, ance a codel.
Scilicet, ance that is to sey [or to wyte.]
Singulatim, ance fro on to an other.
Sirma, i. cauda vestis feminarum, ance a trayne.
Spatula, ance a Cambrel, and a sclyse.
Spectaculum, ance wordelys vanyte. Item est instrumentum iuvans vi∣sum, a spectacle.
Sperula, i. parva spera [et ance a bowle.]
Spinus, ance a Slotre, vel a thorn.
Spola, ance a Quyl, or a Spole.
Sponda, ance a bolster [et ance a forme.]
Spondile, ance the ryggebon [vel the brest bone.]
Sporta, ance a lepe [or a basket.]
Squama, ance a scale or a mayle.
Sterlingus, ance a striylyng or a peys∣peny.
Storium, ance a matte, or a bed.
Strengula, quidam piscis, ance a che∣veyne.
Strido, [ance to grenne or grente with the theth.]
Stupo, ance to stoppe with herdes.
Sturnus, quedam avis, ance a staar.
Subdivo, i. sine tecto vel sub celo, ance theroute.
Subverto, ance to destruye, to turne vpsedoun.
Supera, . . . quedam vestis, ance a roket.
Supero, i. pannum rugare, ance to rydely.
Suppono, ance to undersette, or to suppose.
Suscito, ance to arere, or to areyse.
Tabulatus, ance a kyrnelle of the walle.
Taratantara, . . . est instrumentum quo farina colatur. Et instrumen∣tum cujus percussione granum de∣fluit inter molas molendini, ance a clacke [et ance an hersystete] et est clangor tubarum.
Tardarius, ance a tarcel quoddam genus nisi.
Targia, ance a targat, or a pavys.
Tarinus, quidam vermis lardi, ance a mathe.
Tena vel Tenia, [ance a ffrenge vel a coyfe.]
Tenaculum, [ance a rynge of a dore.]
Tenorcula, ance a telor of an arblast.
Tenta, ance a tente, or an harwe.
Tentigo, i. extensio vel arrectio virilis membri. Item dicitur ance a kyker.
Tentum, ance a tenon, quod ponitur in commissura.
Terebellum i. Furfuraculum, [et ance a Persour.]
Terebrum, ance an augur, or a Persour.
[Terro, i. terram alicui supponere, ance to tere or daube.]
Textum i. semicinctorium, ance a seynt.
Thuribulus, ance a castere of cense.
Timpanum, a taber, or a tymbre.
Tomentum dicitur quia aut in filo aut in tela tumeat, nec subtilitatem ha∣bet, ance abbe.
Toral vel Torale, ance a keverlyt.
Torta et Tortula, a tapur or a torche.
Traha, hoc genus est vehiculi a tra∣hendo dicta, quia rotas non habet, [ance a Dreye.]
Trama . . . est filum inter stamen discurrens, ance abbe, dicitur et quoddam instrumentum textricum quod inequale est. Item Trama, ance an hem.
Tramellum, ance a traysus, vel quod∣dam genus retis, ance a tramayle.
Tremulus, quedam arbor, ance an Apse.
Trepica, i. ocrea, ance a boot.
Trevulgo, to shewe trewys or tretys.
Trochus, et Torpillus, ance a top.
Troparium, quidam liber, ance a tro∣pere.
Trudela, avis est, ance a tele.
Truga, quedam avis, ance a wewe∣strete.
Truta, quidam piscis, ance a trwght.
Tuo, ance to thuy, et dicitur a tu.
Tussimulus, i. pulsatorium, ance the rynge of a dore.
Tutibarum, vel Tutibarium, ance a tum∣brell.
Vacceuallis, hic est locus in silva qua∣dam, ubi sanctus kenelmus occubuit et sepeliebatur, ance Covbach.
Venaticus, ance a brache, vel a rache [or a spaynel.]
Ventilabrum, pala ventilandi, instru∣mentum ventilandi [or a wynne shete.]
Vertebrum, ance a wherve, or a reele.
Vesicula, i. parva vesica. Item dicitur illa tenuis pellicula in gutture avis in qua cibaria congregantur, a croppe, or a case.
Vespa, ance a waps [et est vespa ma∣jor illa, ance an hernet.]
Vetulana, ance an old quene or an old wymman.
Villifico, ance to walle, or to bylle.
Viridarius, ance a hayward, or a Forster.
Vlphus, i. Aleator, ance an hasardour.
Vmbrus, ance a maystyf, or a blode∣hunde.
Zeduarium, quedam herba est, ance zeduale.
Zitanus, i. taxus, ance a brook.

DIV3.HEAD: Additions.
DIV3.P: The original MS. is in the Gale Collection in Trinity College Lib∣rary and the Class mark is O. 5. 4.—The words in square brackets are in a later hand.

Page 560, 561. Add.:
Abdenago . . . interpretaten serviens tacens ance a stylle.

DIV2.HEAD: XVI. METRICAL VOCABULARIES. These curious vocabularies are printed from a manuscript of the fifteenth cen∣tury (MS. Harl. 1002, fol. 113, ro), but the text is in all probability of an earl∣ier date. The name of Spencer is sub∣scribed to the end of it, but names signed in this way are those more usually of the copyist than of the author. From the occurrence in the interlinear gloss of sever∣al words, such as sullow and bannut, peculiar to the dialects of the West of England and the Welsh border, we may perhaps conclude that the MS. was written in that part of the island. The Latin contains a rather large number of words adopted from the Greek. (OF THE FIFTEENTH CENTURY.)

Frenum,brydylle cum chamo,barnaculle I have not before met with this word in the sense of a horse's bit (camus.) postela,cropyn Cropon occurs in the Promptorium Parvulorum as synonymous with crupper. uel antelapaytrelle The strap across the horse's breast. In the early ballad of True Thomas (in the text of the Cambridge MS.), the capar∣ison of the horse is described thus—
Hir paytrelle was of a rialle fyne
Hir cropur was of arafé,
Hir bridulle was of golde fyne,
On every side honge bellis thre. sit.

Stiua,solowhanddul buris,solowbeme aratrum,solow The Anglo-Saxon name of the plow, preserved only in the dialects of the West of England. See before, p. 105, note 2. culter,cultere dentale,chyppe uomerque.chare
Est axisextre duplex, radiispokys sunt, timpana,cartenave canti;vely
Barchasolowborde iugumgoke iungas, hic demum uincula,bonde retorta,wythe
Mallus,bytylle intersimonium,wegge meditiliumque.
Pollicethombe tango liram,harpe facio cum uomereschare liram,vorow
Plaustellum,wayne currus,chare epredia,the þerrepyllis bigaque,carte reda;thylle
Camus,barnaculle cum freno,brydulle lorum,reyne uel abena,idem est capistrum.halter
Est dolabrum,brode axe penitral,persere securis,axe ascia,hachet cerra.sawe
Ensis,swerde sic gladius, seca,idem est basselard The baselard was a long dagger, usu∣ally worn suspended at the girdle. sic sit armicudium.daggar

Pictaciarius,clowtere or cobelere incrustator,tynkere corria,lethere brystylle seta.

Sunt ansoria,baryngsexe The Anglo-Saxon seax. solie,sole sibula,nalle cordibanumque.corduane
Attramentorium,blacchepot sunt attromenta,blacche sed atrum.blacke
Incrustasclowtyst allutam,corduane dic et quitibiale.lest of a boote

Est faber,smyth fullo,towkere A dyer. latamus,mason penulariusskynnere atque

Cironomon,karvere lotrix,lavendere cerotecarius,glovere auceps.fowlere

Pomus,appultre pirus,peeretre corulus,hasyl nux,note auelanaque,bannenote-tre In the dialects of the West of Eng∣land a walnut is universally called a ban∣nut. This is by much the earliest example of the word I have met with. ficus;fygge

Prunus,plumtre uitis,vyne coctanus,qwynstre cornus,hepetre morusque,thewe-thornys The Anglo-Saxon thefe-thorn is usu∣ally explained as meaning the wild-briar, or dog-rose, and ramnus is given as its Latin equivalent. Perhaps it is intended here for the blackberry. sambucus.ellarne
Salix,wythy uolemus,wardentre tremulus,aspe castania,chasteyn quercus;oke

Taxus,ewe sic buxus,boxe abies,vertre ciler,wythy acer addes.mapulle

Edera,yvy pinus,pynetre iuniparus,jenupyrtre labruscaque,wylde vyne mirra.masere
Laurus,baytre lignum,tre ramus,bowe radixmore More, a root, is also a word peculiar to the West of England. or roote sunt arbore, frondes,levys

Instita,a bond capicium,hoode perysomaque,braygurdylle collobiumque;taberde
Thenaque,keyfe caleptra,cappe pilius,pyllyon caligaque,hoose pedana.vampey

Est bumbiciniumkotyn or pakclothe uestis, diploydis,dobelat epifemur,panchere
Papa,pope patriarcha,patryarke cardinalis,cardynalle presul,buschope atque
Archipresul,archebyschope antistes,prelatte or byschop suffraganiussuffrygane sit,
Atque capellanus,chapyllayne sacerdos,prest presbiteridem est addes,

DIV2.TRAILER: Explicit liber Equus caballus, quod Spencer R.

DIV2.HEAD: XVII. NAMES OF THE PARTS OF THE HUMAN BODY. This is printed from the same manu∣script as the preceding more general voca∣bulary, which it follows immediately as a sort of supplement (MS. Harl. No. 1002, fol. 116, vo). (OF THE SAME DATE AS THE PRECEDING.)

LG.L: Os,a mowthe facies,face mentum,chyn dens,tothe guttur,throte lingua,tonge palatum;rofe of þe mowthe
Barba,berde supercilium,browe cilium,brye The eyelashes. frons,forehede tempora,tempelle labrum.lyppe
Palpebraþe lede sunt, acies,sygt oculus,ye albugo,whyte of þe ye pupilla.appulle of þe ye
Purula,cop of þe nose pus nasisnevel of þe nose sunt, interfinia,the brygge of þe nose naris.nostrelle
Sinciput,fore party of þe hede interciput,myddul party occiput,nolle ac cerabrum,the brayne pars
Est capitis,hede cranium,scolle uertex,foretop discrimen,schade of þe here et auris.ere

Palme,pame of þe honde iunctureiutys So has the MS. Read iuntys. R. W. manibushandus sunt, vlna,cubyte lacertus;a feme
Vnguesnayle cum digitis,fyngurys humerus,schuldur cum pectore,breste collum.nekke
Acella,armepytt pugnus,fyste cubitus,a cubyte cum sanguine,blodde mamma;tete
Uenter,wombe uesica,bladdur tergum,bakke spondilia,rybbebone costa.rybbe

Arterie,smal-pypys A rather curious name for the arteries. stomacus,stomake post intestina,inwarde sic epar.lyver
