DIV2.HEAD: XVIII. ENGLISH VOCABULARY. This vocabulary of names of things, in Latin and English, is printed from a manuscript of, I thin, early in the fif∣teenth century, in the old Royal Library in the British Museum, MS. Reg. 17, C. XVII., fol. 21, ro. The MS. contains other tracts of the same character. (OF THE FIFTEENTH CENTURY.)

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA MENBRORUM HO∣MINIS.
LIST.ITEM: Hec ceruex, Ae hartrelle. The crown of the head. The Latin should be vertex instead of cervex. Halli∣well, Dict. of Archaic Words, gives the following illustrative lines from a MS. of the fifteenth century:
Hoc cilium, Ae here of the hee.

ITEM.HI: Hoc intercilium, i. spacium inter cilia.

LIST.ITEM: Hec albugo, Ae wyte of the hee.
Hec pupilla, Ae perylle. Perle means an affection in the eye, apparently what we now call a sty.
Hoc interfinium, Ae bryg of the nese.
Hoc momentum, Read mentum. R. W. Ae chynne.

ITEM.HI: Hec palma, bola, et ir, idem sunt.
Hec vlna est spatium inter manum et capud.

LIST.ITEM: Hoc epilacium, Ae honde-mowle. The honde-mowle appears to have been the palm of the hand. It is the gloss on copinole in Walter de Biblesworth.

ITEM.NOTE: Another vocabulary in the same vo∣lume of MS. (MS. Reg. 17 C. XVII., fol. 38 vo.) gives "uber, -is, Anglice hyddere," the latter word no doubt representing the modern udder.
The glossator has misinterpreted this word and the next. The Nominale in the same MS. (Reg. 17 C. XVII., fol. 39, ro) explains, "hec natis, Anglice luddockes."

LIST.ITEM: Hoc diafragma, Ae myddere. For mydderede, the midriff.
Hoc ren, Ae nere. An old name for the kidney, still preserved in the dialects of East Anglia, though it is more usually employed popul∣arly to denote the fat of the kidneys.
Hoc mandibilum, Ae chewylle. Chewylle, for chowl, or jowl, the jaw.

ITEM.HI: Hec matrix est in qua inuoluitur puer.
Hec uarex, -cis, est quedam uena tendens a uertice capitis vsque ad plantam, que si bedatur reddet ho∣minem curuum.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ANIMALIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic et hec bos, Ae neete.

Hic mannus, Ae rownse. Rounse. A rouncy is generally inter∣preted as meaning a common hackney horse. Thus, in the romance of Ipomydon (Weber, Met. R., vol. ii., p. 340), when the hero went to disguise himself as an half-witted and clownish fellow—
Armure he toke that was rusty,
And horsyd hym on an old rouncy.
Hic oderinsicus, Ae spanegeole. A spaniel.
Hic gargia, Ae gymbure. In Lincolnshire, they still call a female sheep which has been twice shorn a gim∣ber; in the north of England it is called a gimmer.

ITEM.HI: Hec ambigua, est ouis portans duos agnos.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ANIMALIUM FERARUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec melota, Ae broke. The broke was the badger.

ITEM.HI: Hic pardus, est qui generat cum leona.

LIST.ITEM: Hec pantera, Ae pantere, cum multis coloribus.

ITEM.HI: Hic et hec linx, est animal habens oculos acutos.

LIST.ITEM: Hic furestus, uel forestus, Ae forest. The ferret.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA AUIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec nicticorax, Ae nyghterake. The caprimulgus Europaeus, still call∣ed in Yorkshire a night-crow. Its more usual name is night-jar.
Hec miluus, Ae glede. A kite. The Anglo-Saxon name. See p. 132 l. 16.
Hec vpipa, Ae wype. The lapwing.
Hec nodula, Ae kae. A chough. The A.-S. ceo.

Hec frigella, Ae robynet, redbrest. i. e., "little Robin" redbreast. It is the earliest instance of the use of this popular name that I have met with. Robin was a common appellation of affectionate familiarity.

ITEM.HI: Hec marula, est auis habens nigrum rostrum.

LIST.ITEM: Hic vltur, Ae grype. Grype was an old name for the vul∣ture, and is not unfrequently found in that sense in the early metrical romances, though it is sometimes used to signify a griffin.
Hoc rustrum, Ae nebbe. A bird's neb or beak.
Hic capus, Ae muskett. The male of the sparrowhawk.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PISCIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic scorpio, Ae stytlyng. The stickleback.
Hic caput, Ae caboche. The bulhead, or miller's-thumb, called in old French chabot.

ITEM.HI: Hic epimora, est piscis qui moritur eodem die quo nascitur.
Hoc cochile, est quilibet piscis obtecta.

LIST.ITEM: Hic brumillus, Ae brone. Brone, the bream.

ITEM.HI: Hic torpedo, est piscis habens multos pedes.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA UERMIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec irania, Ae erane. Erane, or irane, from the A.-N., was a common name for a spider.

ITEM.HI: Hec teredo, est uermis corodens ligna.

LIST.ITEM: Hic cimex, Ae mawke. Mawke, a maggot, still in use in the northern dialects.
Hec tinea, Ae moke. A moth.
Hec incedula, Ae glydeworme. The glow-worm.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA HERBARUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic ysopus, Ae ysoppe. Ysopus est harba, ysopo spergitur unda.
Hec embroca, Ae maythe. Camomile (the anthemis cotula of bo∣tanists), still called in some districts may weed; the A.-S. mageda. See the A.-S. Vocabularies.
Hic daucus, Ae clapwype. Clap-wype. Daucus is understood to mean the parsnip.
Hic caulus, Ae uwle (?) or thyme.
Hec cuna, Ae croppe. Perhaps it should be cima, the crop, or top, of a plant. The Catholicon has "a croppe, cima."
Hoc uaccinium, Ae cowsokulle. Apparently another name for the cow∣slip.
Hec papauer, Ae chesbolle. Chesbolle was an old name for the poppy.
Hoc gramen, Ae bent. The word bent was applied usually to the long coarse grass growing on the moors, but often in a more general sense to grass of all kinds.
Hoc sirpillum, Ae petergrys. Serpillum is understood as meaning, in the older vocabularies, wild thyme.
Hic cardo, Ae cardoun. Cardon (Lat. carduus), the old French name for the thistle; in modern French, chardon.
Hec gensta, Ae gromylle. Gromylle, the plant now called grom∣well, the lithospermum officinale of bo∣tanists.
Hec lappa, Ae clete. The clote, or yellow water-lilly.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ARBORUM.

ITEM.HI: Regula est quod omnia nomina arborum sunt feminini generis exceptis quatuor, hic oliaster, et hic piaster, hic rubus, et hic dumus. Hic oliaster est vua ste∣rilis.

LIST.ITEM: Hec sambuca, Ae hyllortre. Hyllor, the elder, still called in some parts of England a hilder-tree.
Hec castania, Ae chestantre. Chestan-tre, the chestnut. See before, the note 3 on p. 138.

Hec ficus, Ae fyketre, uel fructus.
Nux, auelana, pirus, glans, et castania, ficus,
Fructum cum ligno sub eodem nomine signo.
Hec sorbus, Ae opynharstre. See before, p. 137 l. 36.
Hec tribulus, Ae brame. i. e., a bramble.

ITEM.HI: Hec singinerperus, est quedam arbor cuius cyneres uolunt ignem seruare per annum.
ITEM.L: Signiperus quod glens pir tibi dicitur arbor,
De gigno, -is, et pir, quod dicitur ignis,
Et cuius cyneres inuolent ardere per annum.

LIST.ITEM: Hec cedrus, Ae sydyretre, et est ta∣lis nature quod nunquam putrescet in aqua nec in terra.
Hec cipressus, est arbor odorissimus et tepida, et habet naturam et ru∣brum colorem, Ae cypyrtre.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA FRUCTUUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hoc uolemum, Ae permayne. A sort of apple, of which Drayton speaks as being a modern importation into our island.
The pearemaine, which to France long ere to us was knowne,
Which careful frut'rers now have denizen'd our owne.
Polyolb., Song xviii.
Hoc malum granatum, Ae pounkarnet. The pomegranate.
Hoc coccinum, Ae quoyne. Quoyne, or coyne, the quince.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA ECCLESIE.
LIST.ITEM: Hec ascera, Ae a lytil chyp.
Hoc semitorium, Ae kyrgarth. The churchyard, still called a kirk∣garth in the north.
Hoc aspersorium, Ae strynkylle. The holy-water sprinkler, or aspersoir.
Hic ambo, -is, Ae letrune. The lectern, or reading desk.

P.HI: Tres sunt partes columne, talus, stilus, et epistilium; uasis est fundamentum, stilus est media pars, epistilium est superior pars.

LIST.ITEM: Hec crisma, Ae creme. The crism, or consecrated oil.
Hec fons, Ae welle. More correctly the font.
Hic absconsus, Ae sconse. A sort of candlestick made to be at∣tached to the wall. The word is still in use for such candlesticks in the north of England.
Hec pixis, Ae boyst. The box for holding the oil, &c., a pyx.
Hoc clamparium, Ae clochere. Read campanarium. R. W.
Hec infula, Ae chesibylle. The MS. has chesibylle or clesibylle. R. W.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ARTIFICIORUM.

ITEM.HI: Hic liricen, qui canit in lira.
Hic secuticen, qui canit in scituta.
Hic tibicen, qui canit in tubia.

LIST.ITEM: Hic frunes, Ae barkare. i. e., a tanner.
Hic architector, Ae thekare. Literally a thatcher.
Hic triculator, Ae tresorre. Tresorre, a treasurer.
Hic seroticarius, Ae glowere. A glover. The Latin word should be cirotecarius, for chirothecarius.
Hic, hec aduena, Ae comelyng. The common name for a stranger or guest.
Hic lixa, idem est quod lixo, Ae quys∣trone.
Hic ninarius, Ninnarius. This low-Latin word, so∣metimes spelt minarius, is usually em∣ployed to signify what we call a wittol, or contented cuckold. Ae cokwalde.
Hic triumphus, Triumphus. This word is not found in this sense in Ducange. Ae constabulle.
Hic capistrius, Ae helterere. Helterer, one who makes halters.

ITEM.HI: Hic cicarius, est ille qui facit cicas.
ITEM.NOTE: Sicarius (incorrectly written cicarius) is here used for one who makes sicas, or daggers.

LIST.ITEM: Hic scarificator, Ae carsare. Carsare. I have not met with this word before. The practice of scarification was extensively employed by the mediaeval surgeons.
Hic sitator, Ae somundare. i. e., a somner.

Hic eruginator, Ae forbushere. Forbushere. This was a business of considerable importance when armour and arms were in general use, and were in continual need of furbishing, or scrubbing. The name Frobisher is probably derived from it.

ITEM.NOTE: This is a very extraordinary use of the word latro.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA FLUMINUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic riuus, Ae syke. Syke is still used in the dialects of the north of England to signify a small stream or gutter.

ITEM.HI: Hoc medianum, est spacium inter aquas.
Hoc amnis, est aqua tantum precens.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA METALLORUM
LIST.ITEM: Hoc auricalcum, Ae latone. The metal formerly called in English laten, or latten, from the French laiton, was a compound of copper, very much resembling brass, which was extensively used in the middle ages, but the exact composition of which seems not now to be known.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ARMORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic pugis, Ae myserecord. Read pugio. Myserecord. This name was given to a thin bladed dagger worn by the warrior, and used to dispatch one who was dangerously wounded, intended, as it is said, to imply that this was an act of mercy. (Cf. pag. 654 l. 16. R. W.)

ITEM.HI: Hec fustis, hic baculus, idem sunt.

LIST.ITEM: Hec gesa, Ae gysserne. The gisarme, or giserne, was the bill or battle-axe. It has been identified with the Latin gesa by an older authority, the commentator on John de Garlande.
Hec balista, Ae awblast. Awblast, the arbalest, or crossbow.
Hec catepulta, a bradharrow. A broad-arrow was distinguished by a large forked head.
Hoc braciolum, Ae brasor. Brasor, the brasser, or armour for the arm.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ORNAMENTORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec pedana, Ae wampe. Vampe, or vampy, bottoms of hose covering the foot; or, perhaps here, the upper leather of a boot.
Hec linistema, Ae tarteryne. Tarterine is described as a king of silk stuff, said to have been so named because it was obtained from the Tartars.
Hec instita, Ae rokytte. Cf. Catholicon Anglicum p. 310 R. W.
Hoc reticulum, Ae kelle. Kelle, a covering of network for the head.
Hoc epitogium, Ae cowrteby. A courtby, or courtpy, was a short cloak of coarse cloth.
Hec carelta, Ae lasse. Lasse, a cassock.
Hec corigia, Ae thowyng. Thowyng, a thong.
Hic pero, -ri, Ae wolyng. Wolyng, a leathern sack.

ITEM.HI: Hoc discriminale, est ornamentum capitis mulieris.

LIST.ITEM: Hec caracalla, Ae kelle. Kelle signifies properly a smock, or petticoat; perhaps it is used here for what we call a smock-frock. (Cf. note 3.)

ITEM.HI: Hoc seruale, idem est quod sertum.
Hec inauris, est annulus in aure.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA INSTRUMENTORUM AULE.
LIST.ITEM: Hec cillaba, Ae tabulle dormawnd. Table dormaunt appears to have been the name for a permanent table in the hall, as distinguished from the board which was placed temporarily upon trestles. The Latin cillaba appears to have been applied to a round table.
Hoc ricrepofocilium, Ae golestok. What is still called in the north a yule-clog, or yule-log.
Hoc sedile, Ae langsedylle. The long wooden seat with back and arms, which is still called a settle.
Hoc scannum, Ae bynke. Bynke, a bench—the usual seat in the hall.
Hoc focale, Ae wode to the fyre.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD PINCERNAM.
LIST.ITEM: Panis similaginius, Ae paynmayn. Payn-mayn was the name given to the bread of finer quality.
Panis auenacius, Ae hafyrbred. Hafyr-bred, bread made of oats; oat∣cakes.
Panis siliginius, Ae tharfbred. This term is now used in the north for unleavened bread.
Hoc libum, Ae wastelle. Wastelle, a cake, the Fr. gâteau.
Hic artocopus, Ae symnelle. i. e., a shive, or slice.
Hic panis, Ae lof of bred.

Hic lesca, Ae scywe. Sanap, a napkin. The romance of Sir Degrevant, l. 1387, speaks of—
Towellus of Eylyssham,
Whygth as the sees fame,
Sanappus of the same,
Thus servyd thei ware.
Hoc ferculum, idem. Farcla sunt frustra, dicuntur fercula uasa.

Hoc gausape, Ae sanap. Sanap, a napkin. The romance of Sir Degrevant, l. 1387, speaks of—
Towellus of Eylyssham,
Whygth as the sees fame,
Sanappus of the same,
Thus servyd thei ware.
Hoc selarium, Ae celare. Celare, a salt-sellar.
Hec sporticula, Ae relef. Relef, a small basket.
Hic vter, Ae buffylle. Buffylle, a leather bottle, for liquors, as would appear from the Latin equiva∣lent.
Hic collator, Ae costylle. Costylle. A costrel was a bottle or vessel of wood, resembling that which the labourers still carry with them in harvest time.
Hoc cepe, Ae hongon. i. e., an onion. From the verse which follows we may perhaps conclude that it was usual to eat onions with cheese. Casius et cepe ueniunt ad prandia sepe.

Hic ducellus, Ae dosylle. Dosylle, the faucet of a barrel. Robert of Gloucester, describing the disturbances in Oxford in the thirteenth century, and the mischief the scholars did in the towns∣men's houses, (ed. Hearne, p. 542), says—
Vor the mer was viniter, hii breke the viniterie,
And alle othere in the toun, and that was lute maistrie;
Hii caste awei the dosils; that win orn abrod so,
That it was pité gret of so much harm ido.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD CAMERAM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec glitella, Ae kostyre. Kostyr, the hanging of the wall of the room—aulaeum.
Hoc stratum, Ae bedlytter. Est lectus stratum, uia regia sit tibi strata.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD COQUINAM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic, hec lixa, Ae quystron. Quystron, the cook's assistant, or scul∣lion.
Hoc micatorium, Ae myowre. Myowr, an implement for reducing bread into crumbs, in old French esmieure.
Hec tripes, Ae burnderthe. Burnderthe, a brandreth, or iron tripot, to place over a fire for supporting a pot or kettle.
Hoc ramentum, Ae ramayle. Ramayle, scrapings.
Hoc uerutum, Ae spit with mete.

Hoc edulium, Ae sowle. Sowle, anything eaten with bread, like cheese, &c., still called in some of the English dialects sool or sowl. Thus, in the romance of Havelok, l. 767—
Kam he nevere hom hand-bare,
That he ne broucte bred and sowel.
Hoc tuncetum, Ae hagase. Hagase. The hagas was the paunch, or stomach, of the animal, stuffed with minced-meat, &c., something in the man∣ner of a sausage; the origin of the modern Scottish haggis.
Caro bouina, beyfflesche. These interpretations would seem to show that the Anglo-Norman terms, beef, pork, &c., had not yet entirely superseded the names of meat of Anglo-Saxon deriv∣ation.
Hic flato, Ae flaune. Wayfire . . . flaune. Wafers were a very light kind of cakes; in old French gauffres; flauns were custards.
Hec artocria, a pie de pundio.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD BRASORIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec cima, Ae kymnelle. Kymnelle, a tub for household pur∣poses; a vat.
Hoc taratantarum, Ae temse. Temse, a sieve. The word is still in use in the North of England.
Hec cuuella, Ae kuulioune Cuvella signifies a small tub.

Hec pruera, lingge. Pruera is a corruption of bruera, and merica of mirica. Ling, the calluna of modern botanists, is introduced here be∣cause it was used largely for making brooms, and other domestic purposes.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD PISTRINUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc fermentum, Ae surdagh. Sur-dagh, i. sour dough.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD ORRIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic abbatis, Ae prowande. Abbatis auenam dat equis abbatis auenam.
Hoc ostorium, Ae stryke. A strike, or bushel measure.
Hec pedana, Ae wampay. Wampay. See before, p. 654 l. 34.

LIST.HEAD: UERBA SOLI DEO PERTI∣NENCIA.
LIST.ITEM: Pluit, raynes, Deus meus. Deus meus etc. is added in a differ∣ent hand-writing. R. W.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD CARECTARIAM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic aculeus, Ae brode. Brode, a prick, or goad.
Hec torques, Ae wythe. A with, or twisted rod.

ITEM.HI: Hec bina, est currus habens duos equos.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD LACTITIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc multrum, Ae chesfat. Ches-fat, a milkpail.
Hec lactis, -cis, Ae cheslypp. Cheslyppe. Perhaps runnet, which is still called cheeselop in the north.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA LUDORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc pedum, Ae cambok. Cambok, an old game at ball played with a crooked stick, mentioned under this name by Stowe.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA DOMORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc fundum, Ae growndwalle. Ground-walle; this is the old Anglo-Saxon term. See before, p. 326 l. 22.

Hoc lodium, Ae lowere. Lowere, a louver/ The open turret, or lantern, on the roof of a building, especially on the old baronial halls, the original object of which was to carry off the smoke from the fire in the middle of the hall.
Hoc ostiolum, Ae hek. Hek is perhaps used in the same signification which it still bears in the north, the lower half of the door, which remains shut while the other half opens.

ITEM.HI: Hoc festum, est lignum ad quod omnia tigna conueniunt.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA AD NUTRIARIUM. The MS. has Nutriariam.—The words follow each other in this chapter as though they had been taken from the "Treatise" of Walter de Biblesworth.

ITEM.HI: Hec emfimenia, serpens cum duobus capitibus.
Hic cholendrus, serpens qui moritur in aquis.
Hec salpia, serpens qui non uidetur.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA AD SUARIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic frendis, Ae galt. Galt, a boar-pig.

ITEM.HI: Hec quinquatria, est domus habens quinque porticus sub se.
Hic, hec parens, est pater uel mater.
Hec socrus, Ae mater in lege.
Hec nurus, Ae filia in lege.
Hic proceser, pater patris in lege.
Hec neptis, est filia filii uel filie.
Hec glos, -ris, est soror in lege.
Hic leuir, est frater in lege.

DIV2.HEAD: XIX. A NOMINALE. A common title for the vocabularies of the fifteenth century was that of No∣minale, intimating that it was strictly a vocabulary of nouns, or names of things, classified under their different heads. The nominale here printed is taken from a very curious MS. of the fifteenth cen∣tury, in the collection of Joseph Mayer, Esq., F.S.A., of Liverpool, which had no doubt belonged to the schoolmaster who taught with it, and remains in its origi∣nal cover of vellum, contrived so as to roll up to make it more portable, with a string attached, to tie it when rolled. It is unfortunately not quite complete, a leaf having been lost; but to judge from the part which remains, that which is lost was probably the least important part of it, and may be supplied from the complete vocabularies of the fifteenth century, printed in the present volume. (OF THE FIFTEENTH CENTURY.)

HEAD.HI: Incipit nominale sub compendio compilatum tam de fixis quam de mobilibus.

LIST.HEAD: DE VOCABULIS AD SINGULA MEMBRA HUMANI CORPORIS SPECTANTIBUS.
LIST.ITEM:
Hoc principium,
Hoc inicium,
Hoc exordium,
Hoc primordium,
Hic origo, A begynnyng.
Hoc discrimen, the schade of the hede. Schede, or shed, was the common name for the separation of the hair on the top of the head, from which it sp read down on either side (= Germ. scheitel. R. W.).

Hic crinis,
Hic capillus,
Hec coma,
Hic pilus, Ace hare.
Hoc tempus, a tunwonge. The Anglo-Saxon þunwang, a temple. See the A.-S. vocabularies in the present volume.

Hec maxilla,
Hec mola,
Hec jaux, A chekbone.
Hoc intercilium, the space betwene the eyn.

Hic oculus,
Hic talmus, Ace ne. Ne, an eye. This practice of prefixing the final n of the article to the noun, when the latter commences with a vowel, is of constant recurrence in these vocab∣ularies of the fifteenth century.
Hec pupilla, the appylle of the ee.

Hec albedo,
Hec albucies,
Hoc albumen, the whyte of the ee.
Hec acies, the scharpnes of the ee.
Hoc interfinium, the bryg of the nese.
Hec purila, the poynt of the nese.
Hic cirrus, a topylle. Topple was used by old writers to signify a tuft or crest.
Hic polipus, the fylth of the nese.
Hec uteelaris, a wongtothe. Wong, or wang, was the A.-S. word for a check; wang-tođ meant a grinder. Wangtooth is, I believe, still used in this sense in the north.

Hec lingua,
Hec glossa, a tonge.

Hoc labium,
Hoc labrum, a lype.
Hec colera, the ersope. A Nominale in MS. Reg. 17, C.XVII., fol. 38, vo, gives, "colera, Anglice arwax."
Hoc ulcus, a kylle. A kile, or ulcerated sore.

Hec gula,
Hoc guttur, a throte.
Hec frontinella, the pyte in the neke.

ITEM.HI: Hoc frumen, i. summa pars gutturis.

LIST.ITEM:
Hec palma,
Hoc ir, irris,
Hec vola, the lone of the hande.

Hec unguis,
Hec ungula, a nayle.

Hec cutis,
Hec pellis, a skyne.

Hoc tergum,
Hoc dorsum, a bake.

Hic venter,
Hic alvuus, a wame.

Hec cawda,
Hec dica, a tayle.

Hoc uber,
Hec mamma,
Hec mamilla, a pape.
Hec pubes, gong hore. i. e., young hair. The Nominale in MS. Reg. 17, C. XVII., fol. 38, vo, ex∣plains pubes and picten (pecten) by "An∣glice rawne."

Hoc femur,
Hoc crus, a the.

Hoc veretrum,
Hic priapus, a pyntyle.

Hic anus,
Hic culus, a ners.

Hoc viscus,
Hoc intestinum,
Hoc extum, a bowyle.
Hoc ren, -is, a nere. Cf. p. 636 note 5.

Hoc adumen,
Hic pinguedo, Ace gres betwen the skyn and the . . .

Hic sanguis,
Hic cruor, Ace blode.
Hec omomestra, a medryn. The midriff.

Hoc stercus,
Hec merda, a torde.
Hoc internodium, the knope of the kne.
Hec medulla, margthe. The marrow; A.-S. mearh, or mearg.
Hic musculus, the calfe of the lege.
Hic fragus, a wyrste. The bend of the knee.

Hic talus,
Hic cals, -cis, a hele.
Hec duricies, hardnes of the hande.
Hec planta, the sole of the fote.
Hoc grabatum, penultima corrupta, a skyrte.

Hoc vulnus,
Hec plaga, a wonde. Recia, regna plage dicuntur, vulnera plage.
Hic passus, a rayke. A step. This word is no doubt con∣nected with the old English word rayke, or rake, to proceed, or go.

Hic regressus,
Hec revercio, a tornyng agayne.

Hic adventus,
Hic accessus, commyng to.

Hic recessus,
Hec discessus, a departynge.

Hoc carecter,
Hoc cicatrix, a nerre. Nerre, a scar, or pock-mark, still called an ar in the north.
Hec lenticula, a frakyn. A spot, or freckle.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA DIGNITATUM CLERI∣CORUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hic presbiter,
Hic sacerdos, a preste.

Hic preco, -nis,
Hic bidellus, a bedylle.

Hic diaconus,
Hec levita, a dekyn.

Hic magister,
Hic pedagogus, a mastyr.

Hic novellus,
Hic novicius, a novys.

Hic citator,
Hic aparator, a summunder.

Hic notarius,
Hic arbiter, a noterer.

Hic modulator,
Hic dictor, -ris, a endyter.

Hic ebdomidarius,
Hic ceroferarius, a cergberare.

Hic chorista,
Hic paraphonista, a qwalester. A querister, or chorister. It is a very unusual form of the word.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA RERUM PERTINEN∣CIUM CLERICO.
LIST.ITEM:
Hoc acuperium,
Hic cos, -tis, a wheston.

Hec zona,
Hoctropheum, media corrupta, a gyr∣dyle.
Hic quaternus, a quare. A quire of vellum or paper. See be∣fore, p. 314 l. 10.

Hic diptica, a smale tabyle. A tablet, or table-book. The common use of table-books in the middle ages has been alluded to more than once in the present volume. According to the Boke of Curtasye (p. 22), the steward of the baronial household set down his accounts in a table-book before they were entered in the regular books—
At countyng stuarde schalle ben,
Tylle alle be brevet of wax so grene
Wrytten into bokes, without let,
That before in tabuls hase ben sett.
For the wax, or other similar substance, a composition was substituted in the course of the fifteenth century, which eventually gave place to what is known as asses' skin.

Hic stilus,
Hic graphus, a poyntyle. The Roman stylus, and Anglo-Saxon groef. See before, p. 314, note 4.

Hoc rasoriu,
Hec novacula, a rasure.
Hoc fulgur, Ace bornston. Bornston, perhaps brimstone.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA DIGNITATUM LAI∣CORUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hic imperator,
Hic induperator, a emperowre.

Hic rex, -gis,
Hic regulus, a kynge.

Hic dominus,
Hic herus, a lorde.

Hic miles, -tis,
Hic eques,
Hic tiro, -nis, a knyght.

Hic armiger,
Hic scutifer, a squyere.

Hic villicus,
Hic prepositus, a grafe. The Anglo-Saxon gerefa, a reeve.

Hic maior,
Hic prefectus, a mayr.

Hic senior,
Hic decrepitus, a nald man.

Hic, hec homo,
Hic mas, a man.

ITEM.HI: Hic aresponsis, i. qui respondit pro principe.

LIST.ITEM:
Hic claviger, a kayberere.
Clava ferit, clavis aperit, clavus duo iungit.
Clavis nos vel vas qui fert sit claviger;
Indue te clavo, rege clavo, percute clavo.

ITEM.HI: Hic centurio, qui habet centum milites.
Hic quaternio, qui habet iiijor milites.
Hic decurio, qui habet x. milites.

LIST.ITEM: Hic panterius, a pantrer. The panter, pantrer, or pantner, was properly the officer of the household who had the care and distribution of the bread (panis); and the pantry was especially the bread department of the household.
Hic, hec lixa, a kychyn page. Or a quistron.

Hic predo,
Hic vespilio, a robber.
Hic primiplus, qui habet primam ber∣bam.
Hic primipilus, qui fert pila ad prelia.
Primipilus berbam primam desingnat ha∣bentem,
Ast primipilus qui fert ad prelia pila.
Hic cimiflo, a naskkyste. Called more usually an askfyse, the servant who made and blew the fire.

Hic exelerarius, a byrler. The attendant who served the wine. The verb birle, (A.-S. birlian) to draw or pour out wine, is not an uncommon word in the old writers. In the metrical ro∣mance of The Avowynge of King Arther (Robson's Metr. Rom., p. 80), we are told that there was at a great feast—
—rialle servys and fyne,
In bollus birlutte thay the wyne.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ARTIFICIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic revelus, a peder. Pedder was the old name for a pedlar.
Hic piscarius, a fychmanger. Piscator prendit quod piscarius bene vendit.

Hic serdo,
Hic frunitor, berkere. i. e., a tanner.
Hic urigenator, a frobycher. See before, p. 652, note 8.
Hic tinctor, a lytster. Lytster, a dyer.

Hic sutor,
Hic aluterius, a sowter. Sowter, a shoemaker; the Latin sutor. It is preserved in the Scottish dialect.
Hic cribrarius, Acce fysmaker. From the Latin word, this would seem to mean a maker of sieves. Perhaps it should be syfmaker.
Hec murida, a ratunner. A rat-catcher.
Hic lorinarius, a loryner. A maker of horses' bits.
Hic carbonerius, a colger. i. e., a collier.

Hic circumforarius, a mycher. A micher means one who goes sneak∣ing about for improper purposes, as to steal on the sly, to act as a messenger in illicit amours, &c. In the latter sense, the verb to mich was in common use among the Elizabethan writers.
Hic plantator, a nymper. Properly one who grafts, or who plants settings of trees. From the A.-S. impian, to graft, or plant.
Hic stinarius, a halder. The man who held the plow.
Hic smigmator, a sopseler. A dealer in soap. Smigma is usually taken for an unguent for perfuming, or pomatum.
Hic ceparius, Acce ungonseller. i. e., a seller of onions.
Hic depositor, a serofer in halle.

Hec familia, a menge. More properly written maisnie (from the Anglo-Norman), the household; the whole attendance upon the personal esta∣blishment of the feudal lord. It has no connection whatever with the word many (the Anglo-Saxon manig).
Hic, hec comes, Acce a felow.

Hic infans,
Hic pucio,
Hic puer, Acce a chylde.

ITEM.HI: Hic adolescens, est puer xiiijcem an∣norum.
Hic decrepitus, ille qui vadit cum baculo.
Hic verbius, -ui, qui est beatus vel qui habet uxorem.
Hic libertinus, Acce ille qui fit liber.

LIST.ITEM: Hic, hec pifundabalista, Acce a slynger
Hic texillaris, a spy in batylle.

ITEM.HI: Hic cathecuminus, noviter conversus et non baptizatus.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA CONSANGUINITATIS ET AFFINITATIS.
LIST.ITEM: Hec triava, the thyrd fro the modyre.
Hic abavus, the secund fro thy fadyr.
Hec abava, the secunde fro the modyr.
Hic avus, Acce a neld fadyre.

Hic filius,
Hic natus, a sune.

Hec filia,
Hec nata, Acce a dowghter.

Hic avunculus,
Hic patruus, a neme.

Hec ameta,
Hec matertera, a nawntt.

Hec filiaster,
Hec previgna, a stepdowghter.
Hic gemellus, a twynlynge of men.
Hec gemella, a twynlynge of women.

ITEM.HI: Hic abortivus, i. non suo tempore ortus.

LIST.ITEM: Hic postimus, he that is born aftyr the deth of hys fadyre.

ITEM.HI: Hic proculius, est filius natus patre existente procul.
Hec proculia, est nata patre exi∣stente procul.

LIST.ITEM:
Hic sponsus,
Hic coniunx, a husband.

Hec sponsa,
Hec coniunx, a wyfe.

Hoc coniugium,
Hoc sponsale, a maryage.

ITEM.HI: Hic levex, i. frater mariti uxoris.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA DIGNITATUM MULIERUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec domina,
Hec hera, a lady.

Hec abra,
Hec ancilla, a burwoman. i. e., a chambermaid.

Hec puella,
Hec ampha, a madyn.
Hec rustica, Acce a feldman wyfe.

ITEM.HI: Hec sacerdotissa est femina dans sacra.
Hic, hec sinobita, qui vel que manet in sinobio.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ARTIFICIUM MULIERUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec apoticaria, Acce a spyser wyfe.

LIST.HEAD:
NOMINA IUGULATARUM MULIERUM. A Nominale in MS. Reg. 17, C. XVII., fol. 43, vo, gives the following rather curious list relating to minstrelsy and games:
Hic castrator, Anglice lybbere.
Hic prestigiator, Anglice mynstralle.
Hec cithera, Anglice harpe.
Hec lira, Anglice harpestryng.
Hoc plectrum, Anglice warste.
Hic citheredus,
Hec cithereda, Anglice harpure.
Hic tubicen,
Hec tuba, Anglice troumpe.
Hic fidis, Anglice fydellere.
Hec viella, Anglice fedylle.
Hic arculus, Anglice fydylstyk.
Hic gigator, Anglice getyrnere.
Hec giga, Anglice getyrne.
Hic simbolisator, Anglice crowde.
Hoc simbolum, Anglice scotnyng.
Simbolisare, to crowde or scotnyg.
Hic simphonia, Anglice mynstrylsy.
Hic corallus, Anglice crowdere.
Hec coralla, Anglice crowde.
Hoc psalterium, Anglice sawter.
Hoc organum, Anglice orguns.
Hoc simpharium, Anglice synfan.
Hic joculator,
Hic mimus, Anglice jogulour.
Hic tripidiator, Anglice dawnsere.
Hoc tripudium, Anglice dawnse.
Hec corea, Anglice carolle.
Hec fascia, Anglice credilsang.
Hic fistulator, Anglice pypere.
Hec fistula, Anglice pype.
Hic excubius,
Hic expolator, Anglice wayte.
Hec colomaula, Anglice waytepype.
Hoc expiridium, Anglice rede.
Hec saltatrix, Anglice tumbullere.
Hic gestiarius, Anglice gester.
Hic scurra, Anglice harlot.
Hic nugator, Anglice iaper.
Hec nuga, Anglice iape.
Hic nugigerulus, Anglice trifulere.

ITEM.HI: Hec secutissina, que canit in secuta.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA REPREHENSIBILIUM UIRORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic leno, -nis, baustrott. Baustrott, a bawd.

Hic fenerator,
Hic usurator, a usurer.
Hic et hec scurra, a rebalde.
Hic et hec fur, a theffe.

Hic ereticus,
Hic sismaticus, a herytik.
Hic muricidus, a losynge. Losynge, a worthless fellow.

ITEM.HI: Hic bilinguis, qui habet binas linguas.

LIST.ITEM: Hic pelinguis, a horcoppe. i. e., a bastard.

ITEM.HI: Hec, hic patricida, Acce que vel qui occidit patrem.
Hec, hic matricida, que vel qui occi∣dit matrem.
Hec, hic parenticida, qui vel que oc∣cidit

LIST.ITEM: Hic duribuctus, a dasyberd. Dasyberd, a simpleton, or fool.
Hic et hec armifraudita, a skratt. Skratt, a hermaphrodite. The word is still in use in the dialects of the north of England. It is the pure Anglo-Saxon word.

ITEM.HI: Hic, hec apostita, qui bene incipit et statim recedit.

LIST.ITEM: Hic nerenus, idem est. Hunc dico zelotopum cui non sua sufficit nxor.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA REPREHENSIBILIUM MULIERUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec meritrix,
Hec tabernaria, a strumpytt.
Hec saga, a wech. i. e., a witch.
Hec pronuba, a bawdstrott. Bawdstrott. The meaning of the word is here identical with that in which it is used in a preceding chapter.
Hec elena, Acce a strumpytt. Est meretrix elena, virgo vocatur Elena.
Hec caupana, Acce a taverner wyffe.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA RERUM PERTINEN∣CIUM UXORI.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc lapsum, a top of lin.
Hic folliculus, a betylle. Betylle, the instrument with which the flax was beaten.
Hic linipolus, a stric of lyne. Stric, perhaps strike, a measure.
Hec troilia, a trindylle. The wheel. It is still in use in the dialect of Derbyshire.
Hoc multrum, a kytt. A pail.
Hec lamia, slay. The name for a part of the weaver's loom.
Hoc lacinatorium, a slekstone. Perhaps for flekstone. The Latin licia∣torium is interpreted in later vocabularies as the yarnbeam.
Hec trama, Acce a wefte. The woof.
Hec forigo, a lystynge. The list of cloth.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA JUGULATORUM.

ITEM.HI: Hic secuticen, qui canit in secuta.
Hic cornuten, qui canit a cornu.
Hic choricista, qui canit in choro.
Hic barbatissa, qui canit in barbita.

LIST.ITEM: Hic et hec lerecen, a herper.

ITEM.HI: Hic, hec coraula, qui vel que ducit coria in aula.
Hic organista, qui ludit ad organa.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA OPERARIORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic triturator, Acce a tasker. Tasker, i. e., a thrasher. The word is now used in some dialects for a reaper; perhaps so named as working by task, or piece.

Hic runcator,
Hic circulator, lowker. A weeder.
Hic colibertus, Acce a carle. The sense here given to the word carle, as synonymous with collibertus, generally taken to signify a freedman, is curious.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ANIMALIUM DOMESTI∣CORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic caballus, Acce a cabylle. i. e., a capul, or horse of burthen.

ITEM.HI: Hic admissarius, equus qui portat arma.

LIST.ITEM: Hec juvenca, a qwye. Quye, a female calf.
Hec ovicula, idem est. Que male fetet ovis non est melior tribus . . . .
Hec cenaria, Acce a cad. Cad. This word is at present used in the dialect of the eastern counties to sig∣nify a very small pig.

Hec aries,
Hec berbex, Acce weder.

Hic singulus,
Hic aper, Acce a bore.

ITEM.HI: Hic burdo, i. genitum inter equum et asinam.
Hic luciscus, est canis genitus inter canem et vulpem.
Hec lucisca, est canicula similiter nata.

LIST.ITEM: Hic caniculus, a kenet. A small species of hunting dog, ment∣ioned often in the old writers on the chase, and not uncommonly in the metrical ro∣mances, and supposed by some to be equi∣valent with our harrier. The word, however, seems to be often used as the simple equi∣valent of a hound.
Hic catulus, a kytylyng. A kitten.

ITEM.HI: Hec polea, est colleccio vel pluralitas quorumcunque bestarum.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA FERARUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec lea,
Hec leena, Acce a lyonys.

Hec capra,
Hec dacas, Acce a rabuke.

Hic glis,
Hic sorex, Acce a dormows.

ITEM.HI: Hic nex, -cis, media producta, animal simile capre.

LIST.ITEM: Hic sinozephalus, a mancowe. Mancowe, a baboon.
Hic fetoutrus, Acce a fulmard. A polecat. The word is still in use in the northern dialects.

ITEM.HI: Hic linx, animal penetrans parietes visu oculorum suorum.

LIST.ITEM: Hic gamelion, animal varii coloris et sola aere vivit, a buttyrfle.
Hic onager, Acce a wyld has.

ITEM.HI: Hic spinx, vermis lucens in noctibus.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA VOLATILIUM DOMESTICORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic, hec natis, -tis, Acce a malerde.

Hic signus,
Hic olor, Acce a swanne.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA VOLATILIUM INCOMESTILIUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hic ibis, -dis,
Hic ibex, -cis, a snype.
Hic onocrotalus, a butturre. The bittern.
Hec upipa, Acce a wype. Wype, the lapwing.
Hec vespertilio, a bake. Bake was the old form of bat.

Hic picus.
Hec pica, a pye.
Hic irundo, a swalo. Crescit harundo, sugit hirudo, canit hirundo.
Hec toda, a wagsterd. Wagsterd, probably the water-wagtail.
Hic regulus, a wrenne. Regulus est serpens, avis, et rex parvnlus omnis.
Hec frigella, a roberd. The chaffinch.
Hic phenix, media producta, a phenes.

Hec lucinia,
Hic carduelis, a goldfynche.
Hic palustris, a redesparowe. The reedsparrow.
Hic ficedula, a nuthage. Nuthage, the nuthatch.
Hec fulceca, a semawe. Semawe, probably the sea-mew.
Hic pratellus, a buntyle. Buntyle, the bunting, or woodlark.
Hic virudiarius, a ruddoke. The robin. See, on the popular name of this familiar bird, a former note, p. 640.
Hec discipula, a swyke. Swyke, a trap, or snare, for birds.

LIST.HEAD: PARTES ANIMALIUM BRUTORUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec cornu, indeclinabile, a horne.
Corna gerit cornus, pecudum sunt cor∣nua . . .
Militis est quando properat sua bella ge∣rendo.
Hec crista, est crinis vel quod eminet super galeam et super capita quo∣rundam animalium, the cokcome.
Hic pugio, -nis, a tange. Tange, a sting, still used in the north of England.
Hoc ilum, the pyf of the penne.
Hic villus, a lok of wolle.

Hec brancia,
Hec senecia, a gylle.
Hec lactis, a cheslepe. Rennet is still called cheeselope in the north.

ITEM.HI: Hec membrana, est pellis ale vesper∣tilionis.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PISCIUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic piscis, a fyche. Hic editur piscis, hec servat aromata pixis.

ITEM.HI: Hec belua, i. animal magnum m[a]ris.

LIST.ITEM: Hic cetus, a whalle. Est hominum coetus, set vivit in equore cetus.

Hec amphinia,
Hic delfinis,
Hec foca, a porpas.

Hic polanus,
Hic pecten, a place.

ITEM.HI: Hic molanurus, piscis qui magnam caudam [habet].

LIST.ITEM:
Hoc ostrium,
Hec ostria, a nostyre.

Hic polipus,
Hec gorra, a lopster.

ITEM.HI: Hec cepia, est piscis de quo fit caustum.

LIST.ITEM:
Hic sperlyngus,
Hic thimalus, a sperlynge.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA VERMIUM ET MUSCARUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hic ibis, -dis,
Hic coluber, a neddyre.

ITEM.HI: Hoc amphibim, est serpens cum tribus capitibus.

LIST.ITEM:
Hic jaculus,
Hic biceps, a flyande eddyre.

Hec arena,
Hec aranea, a nerane.
Hic multipes, a welbode. Welbode, a woodlouse.

ITEM.HI: Hoc tumultum, est vermis in cornubus arietum.
In plurali numero hee serene sunt serpentes volantes.

LIST.ITEM:
Hic rambricus, a paddoke. Paddoke. Possibly the Latin should be lumbricus, which is explained in the next glossary as signifying a tadpole. There appears to have been always some little diversity in the use of the word paddok. In some of the modern English dialects it is applied to a frog. We might naturally suppose it to be a diminutive of pade, which was also a name for a toad; and a passage in the Coventry Mysteries, p. 164, evidently makes a distinction bet∣ween the two words—
I scal prune that paddok, and prevyn hym as a pad.
An English gloss of the latter part of the fourteenth century (Reliq. Ant., vol. i., p. 8), explains the Latin rana by a paddoke, which agrees with the English provincial use of the word just alluded to.
Hec polemita, a somerboyde. The same Latin word is explained in the next glossary by a bude—apparently a species of bettle.
Hec sicoma, a myge. A midge, or gnat.
Hic brucus, a breas. The breeze, or gadfly.
Hic crabius, Perhaps for crabro, a hornet. a cercole.
Hec apaphsibena, a nedyr with ij. hedes.

ITEM.HI: Hic papheas, serpens cum grosso ca∣pite.
Hec bredraca, serpens habens faciem hominis.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA MORBORUM ET INFIR∣MORUM VIRORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc glandulum, a waxkyrnylle. Waxkyrnylle. Palsgrave has the word waxenkernel, which is explained as mean∣ing an enlarged gland in the neck.

Hec podegra,
Hic perneo, a mowlle.
Hic gibbus, a boche in bake.
Hec struma, a boch in the brestes.

ITEM.HI: Hic bubo, -nis, i. morbus sub ano.

LIST.ITEM:
Hoc vulnus,
Hec plaga, a wonde.

ITEM.HI: Hic, hec intereus, est morbus inter
In plurali hec menstrua, sunt infir∣mitates mulierum.

LIST.ITEM:
Hic pruritus,
Hec prurigo, a gekynge.

ITEM.HI: Hec dissentaria, est divicio vel ulce∣ratio intestinorum.

LIST.ITEM:
Hec lentigo,
Hec lenticula, a frakkyne. A freckle.
Hec sinax, -cis, pursenes, vel quod∣dam festum.
Hec gutturna, the qwynse, et inde gut.
Hec glaucoma, a the gowyl sowght.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA INFIRMORUM.

ITEM.HI: Hic erecticius, qui vexatur multis demonibus.

LIST.ITEM: Hec stroba, a woman glyande. Glyande, squinting.

ITEM.HI: Hic et hec loripes, qui habet pedem ligneum.

LIST.ITEM: Luscus, -a, -um, he that is sand∣blynde. Sandblind, i. e. dimsighted.

ITEM.HI: Hic lanaculus, qui fert lanam ad oculos tergendos.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ARBORUM ARABILIUM ET FLORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec maguderis, a calstok. Calstok, called in the Prompt. Parv. a calkestoke, is explained by Palsgrave pie de chou, and is supposed to mean the stalk of the cale, or colewort.
Hoc sepe, a nongone. An onion.
Hec sepa, a chesbolle. The word can hardly mean here a poppy.
Hec fantula, idem est. Fantulus est filius, sed fantula crescit in ortis.
Hoc apium, smalege. Smallage, or wild celery (the apium graveolens of botanists).
Hic cucumur, vel-mis, a palmernutte. Palmer-nutte. The next vocabulary explains cucumer by a flage.
Hec buglossa, oxtunge. Bugloss, the lycopsis arvensis of bot∣anists.

ITEM.HI: Hoc folium, est herba natans sine radice.

LIST.ITEM:
Hoc felicetum,
Hoc filacerium, a brakynbuske.
Hic cirpus, hic junccus, a rysche.
Hic papirus, a sene. The wild nasturtium.
Hec elena campana, horshalle. Called elsewhere horsehelin.
Hec uticella, haryffe. Haryffe. In Gloucestershire the name hairiff is given to the plant called more usually cleavers, or goose-grass (apium aparine); in the north it is applied to catchweed.
Hec amarusa, donfinkylle. Perhaps amarusa is a corruption of amaracus, which is explained differently as meaning sweet marjoram (origanum vulgare), or feverfew (pyrethrum par∣thenium).

Hoc glustrum, flowrd of feld. Unde invenitur metrice de beata virgine:
O mater, glustri decor, candorque ligustri,
Labe cadens lustri, necnon et sorde palustri,
Nato prelustri me jungas more colustri,
Ne regar amplustri Satane per lirida lustri.

ITEM.HI: Hec caperis, i. herba frutex spinosus.

LIST.ITEM: Papaver, Ae a chespolle. A poppy. See p. 710 l. 27.

LIST.HEAD: DE NOMINIBUS SPECIERUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec species, -ei, spyce.
Est species logicus, est altera grammati∣corum,
Estque genus species, species et forma virorum,
Est eciam species gratum quod prestat odorem;
Totque modus species viriatur quot mo∣nitorem.

Hoc amigdalatum, almund-mylk. Almond-milk, or almond-cream, ap∣pears to have been a favourite article in the pastry and dessert department during the middle ages. The Forme of Cury (p. 17) gives the following receipt for making a "cawdel of almand-mylk": "Take almandes blanched, and drawe hem up with wyne; do therto powdor of gynger, and sugar, and color it with saffron; boile it and serve it forthe." It seems to have con∣tinued in fashion until at least the end of the seventeenth century, as would ap∣pear from the following extract from one of the popular dramatists of that age:
"The devil take me, I love you so, that I could be content to abjure wine for ever, and drink nothing but almond-milk for your sake."—Shadwell, Epsom-Wells, 1673.
Hec ficus, a fyke, or a fikes. Hic ficus morbus, hec ficus fructus et arbor.
Hic gariofilus, a cloyfe. Cloyfe, a clove.
Hoc unium, vyneloun. Vyneloun, a sort of spice.
Hoc examen, lingua bilancis. Est examen apum colleccio, lingua bi∣lancis.

ITEM.HI: Hec dragma, est octava pars uncie.

LIST.ITEM: Hoc ponde, a fowdrelle. Res sit vera staterem portate statera.

ITEM.HI: Hic bipondus, i. genus ponderis ex duabus assibus appositum.

LIST.ITEM: Hec massa polatarum, a frayle ful of fyks.
[Hic dactilis, Acc an almonde]. This line is written in a rather later hand than the rest of the manuscript.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ARBORUM ET EARUM FRUCTUUM.

ITEM.HI: Hoc piretum, est locus ubi crescunt.

LIST.ITEM: Hoc pepulum, a bolysse. i. e., a bullace (prunus insititia).
Hec avelana, a walnutte and the nutte.
Hec ficus, -ci vel -cus, a figtre or a fig.
Hec castania, a cheston, or the tre.
Hec ramnus, -ni, a thethorntre. Generally interpreted as the dog rose, or wild briar, called þefe-þorn by the Anglo-Saxons. See before the Auglo-Saxon Vocabularies.
Hoc fraccinum, a kay of a nesche.

ITEM.HI: Hoc bidellium, i. arbor dans bonum o[dorem].

LIST.ITEM: Hec cocianus, a coventre. The coigne-tree, or quince.
Hec mespulus, a meltre. The medlar, mespilus germanica.

ITEM.HI: Hec nucliarius, est quelibet arbor ferens nuces.

LIST.ITEM:
Hec silva,
Hec indago, a woyd.

ITEM.HI: Hic titrus, arbor que cito surgit.

LIST.ITEM: Hec volemus, a warduntre. The warden was a large coarse pear used for baking.
Hec merica, media producta, a brome.

ITEM.HI: Hoc rubietum, ubi crescunt vel ru∣biant.

LIST.ITEM:
Hic tribulus,
Hec vepres,
Hec veprecula, a brere.
Hoc virgultum, a halte. A holt, or copse.
Hec viprex, -icis, a schyd. Schyd means usually a billet of wood.
Hoc abdomen, grundsope. Grund-sope. This appears to be a different meaning of the word to that which it usually bears. The Prompt. Parv. gives, "Growndesope of any lycoure, fex, sedi∣men."

Hic ramus,
Hic ramusculus, a braunche.
Hec palmes, -tis, a brawnch of vyne.
Hic racemus, a brawnch of grapys.

ITEM.HI: Hec labrusca, est agrestis vitis, vel botrus amarus.

LIST.ITEM:
Hoc germen,
Hec pululacio, a burjonyng.

Hec astula, -e,
Hec quisquilie, a chype.

Hic rogus,
Hic fax, -cis, a bronde.
Hic faciculus, a kynch. Kynch must here mean a small bundle.
Hec cima, the crop of a tre. Cima caput virge, verborum gloria sema

Hic fullus, a fylberdtre. The Latin should be fillis. "Filberde∣tree, phillis," Prompt. Parv. Gower, Con∣fes. Amant. vol. ii., p. 30 (ed. Pauli), has misrepresented the story of Phillis and Demophoon, in Ovid, in order to give a derivation of this word—
And Demephon was so reproved,
That of the Goddes providence
Was shape suche an evidence
Ever afterward ayein the slowe,
That Phillis in the same throwe
Was shape into a nutte-tre,
That alle men it mighte se,
And after Phillis philliberde
This tre was cleped in the yerd.

Hoc condimum, a wardun.
Arborium nomen femininum dic fore semper,
Ni rubus, dumus, oliaster, sive piaster,
Adda viburnum predictis, addito vimen.

LIST.HEAD: HEE SUNT PARTES FRUCTUUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec perima,
Hec peripsima, a paryng.
Hec pertica, the sterte The stalk. of a napulle.
Hec testa, a schelle, vel cortex nucis.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA DOMORUM ET RERUM ECCLESIASTICARUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec ecclesia,
Hoc templum,
Hoc delubrum,
Hoc fanum,
Hec basilica, a kyrk.

Hic cancellus,
Hic chorus, a chawnsylle.
Hoc alphabetum, a nabse. i. e., an abc.
Hec biblioteca, a bybulle. Biblioteca mea servat meam bibliotecam.

Hec ymago,
Hec statua, a ymage.

Hec confirmacio, confyrmynge.
Baptismum proprie fertur mundacio mentis,
Exterior querit per aquam, baptisma vocatur.
Hec vox baptismus signat utrumque simul.

ITEM.HI: Hic catecuminus, est ille qui est con∣versus ad fidem et non est bapti∣zatus.

LIST.ITEM: Hic calix, -cis, a chalys. Vas cleris vinique calix est et nomen inertis.
Hec pixis, -dis, a box. Hie editur pissis, hic servat aromata pixis.
Hoc ostiarium, a obley, or a box.

Hoc thus, -ris,
Hoc thimiama,
Hoc incensum, encens.

Hec acerra, a schyp for censse. The nef, a vessel in the form of a ship, used in the church from an early period to hold the incense, as well as other articles. A similar vessel was used at the baronial table to hold wine, &c.

Hoc feretrum,
Hic loculus,
Hec libitina, a ber.
Hec lucerna, a lantron. A lantern.
Hec absconsa, a scons. See before, p. 649 l. 18.
Hec fanula, a fanune. The priest's maniple.

Hec casula,
Hec poderis, a chesapulle.
Hoc pedum, a clappe. Pedum occurs again below, where it is explained as a crowche, or pastoral staff.
Hec dalmatica, a canturcope. We must conclude, from the Latin equivalent, that this word signifles a maniple.

Hic torticus,
Hec teda, -e, a sergberger.
Hec secula, a rysch. Rysch, a rushlight.

Hic stilus, a peller.
Est stilus unde scribit puer, stilus esto columna,
Dictandique modus ducitur esse stilus.

Hoc ventilogium,
Hec cheruca, a wedyrcoke.

Hoc semitorium,
Hoc atrium, a kyrkgerd. Atria dic aulas, eadem semitoria dicas.

Hic certofagus,
Hoc mauseolum,
Hic tumulus,
Hec tumba,
Hoc poliandrum,
Hoc bustum, a grave.

Hoc glossum, a schryn.
Mandai. opilio vetat mandrumi. ovem licosi. lupi intrare meandrumdyssatt
Clausit Alexandrum magnum parvum poliandrum.

Hec capsa,
Hec capsulla,
Hec capcella,
Hec cista, a kyst.
Hec crupta, a hol in the erthe. Per quem fit crupta, non fiunt carmina scripta.

ITEM.HI: In plurali hec sacerdotorum dicuntur loco inferiora, ad que omnis erit a . . . . nus sacerdotibus.

LIST.ITEM:
Hoc centorium,
Hoc tabernaculum, a tabernakylle.

Hic turrus,
Hec arax, a towre.

ITEM.HI: Hic citus, est passio vel mari domus.

LIST.ITEM: Hoc messuagium, a messe. A mansion, or manor.
Hoc Syon, indeclinabile, Syon. Montem dic Syon, dic ecclesiam fore Syon.

ITEM.HI: Tres sunt partes columne, s. basis, stilus, et epistilium; basis est fun∣damentum, stilus est media pars, et epistilium est supprema pars.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA DOMO PERTINENCIA.
LIST.ITEM: Hec cambuca, a cambok. Cambuck, and the medieval Latin words Cambuca, or cambuta, were used in the sense of a bent or crooked staff or beam, and here perhaps means some im∣plement for supporting or suspending ar∣ticles, like those by which butchers hand up carcases of slaughtered animals.

Hic corbes,
Hoc dolium, a tune.
Hoc nectar, -ris, pyment. Fex vini tibi sit, olei dicatur amurca.
Hec mensacula, a bordknyf. i. e., a carving-knife.

Hic contus,
Hec pila, a postyke. A pestle.
Hic ursiolus a posnet. A skillet, or small pot.

ITEM.HI: Hec ampulla, est olla cum duabus auribus.

LIST.ITEM: Hic perapsis, -dis, a dobler. A dobler. The same Latin word is explained in the next vocabulary a platter.
Hoc striaballum, a cog of a welle.
Hec vertybra, a colrak. A coal-rake, or implement for raking the ashes of a fire.

Hoc idromellum, growtt. Growtt, a sort of ale. In the old play of Tom Tyler and his Wif, this liquor is mentioned in the two verses of a song—
This jolly grout is jolly and stout,
I pray you stout it still-a.

Hec cuva,
Hec uva, a fat.

Hic corbis,
Hec sporta, a lepe.

Hec garba,
Hec merges, a schaffe.
Hoc osorium, a strikylle. A strickle, or piece of wood for le∣velling the corn in the measure.
Hoc ventilabrum, a scotylle. Scotylle, a winnowing-fan.
Hoc exaticum, byge. A kind of barley.
Hic vomer, vel hec, -mis, a seke.
Hec liga, vel mera, a pyk.

Hoc terubrum,
Hoc penetrale a wymbylle.
Hoc armoriolum, a nalmry. An aumbry, or cupboard, formed from the Low Latin word almariolum.

Hic mergus,
Hec situla, a bokytt.
Hec cavilla, a nayle or a pyn.
Hec singula, a horsgarthe. Scingula scingit equum, singula sunt ho∣minum.
Hoc ligatorium, a tedyre. Tedyre, a cord to tie an animal to a stake, still called in Kent a tether.
Hoc bolideum, a plum of lede.
Hec roga, almus. Hic rogus est ignis, elemosina sit roga dicta.
Hec falx, a sykyl, or a seth.

LIST.HEAD: JAM DE EDIFICIIS DOMORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc edificium, a bygyng. Bygyng, a building; from the A.-S. bicgan, to build.

Hec talamus,
Hec camera,
Hic conclavis,
Hec zeta, a chambyre.
Hoc celarium, a spens. The spense, or buttery.
Hec amissis, a swyer. The Latin word amussis means a carpenter's rule.
Hec fornix, -icis, a bordylhows. A brothel; from the Anglo-Norman; the modern French bordel.
Hoc gazafilacium, a hordhows. A treasury; the Anglo-Saxon word.

ITEM.HI: Hec vinarium, est locus ubi vinum reponitur.
Hec lapidisina, est domus latamorum, vel est ubi lapides ceduntur.

LIST.ITEM:
Hoc toloneum, a tolboythe.
Qui mausoleum producit, aut canopeum,
Seu toloneum, non reor esse reum.

ITEM.HI: Hoc triclinium, est domus trina ses∣sione f[acta].

LIST.ITEM: Hoc apendicium, a pentys. A pentise, or shed over a door.

ITEM.HI: Hoc repositorium, est locus ubi ali∣quid repo[nitur].
Hoc argasterium, ubi aliquid opus fit.

LIST.ITEM:
Hec antica, a hek. Hek. A heck-door, in the north, is a door of which the lower part only is panelled, and the upper latticed. The word, which is not very common in this sense in old writers, occurs in the Townley Mysteries, which were written in the North (p. 106)—
Good wyff, open the hek, seys thou not what I bryng.
It is explained in the glossary as "the inner door between the entry or lobby, and the house or kitchen."

Hec postis,
Hec postellus, a post.
Hoc signaculum, a bretys. A bretasche.

Hoc saxum,
Hec petrilla,
Hec petra, a stone.
Hec calx, -cis, lyme. Pars pedis est hic calx, lapis ustus dici∣tur hec calx.
Hic tignuus, vel hoc tegimen, a sparre.
Hec grunda, a eskyng. Eskyng. A pentise is called an esking in Lincolnshire.

ITEM.L: Dic epicausterium scriptoris esse cathedra.
Est epicausterium fornax ubi dequoquis ollas.
Ast illud longum que fumus ab ede recedit.

LIST.ITEM: Hec pinna, est summitas cujuslibet rei. Sit tibi montis apex, dicas pinna quoque templi.

Hoc tabellatum, a burdwogh. Burd-wogh, a wall, or partition, of boards—a wainscot. We meet with the Anglo-Saxon bord-weall, used in much the same way. It may be here remarked that the distinction between wall and wogh, in English, was the same as be∣tween the original words in Anglo-Saxon, namely, the latter was applied peculiarly to the walls of a house, and the former to a wall of enclosure, or separation, in general. Thus, in the following lines, Gower, telling the story of Pyramus and Thisbe, informs us that they lived so close together, that the walls of their houses, and those of their court or yard, adjoined to each other—
Amonge the which, two there were
Aboven all other noble and great,
Dwellend tho within a strete
So nigh to-gider, as it was sene,
That there was nothing hem betwene,
But wowe to wowe and walle to walle.
Gower, Conf. Amantis, vol. i., p. 324, ed. Pauli.
Hoc fenestrale, a fenestralle. A fenestral was a window formed of a frame of paper and cloth, instead of glass.

Hec porta,
Hec janua,
Hee bifores, -rium,
Hee fores, a gatt.
Hic cardo, -nis, penultima corrupta, a har of a dore. Har, a hinge. In the dialect of Dur∣ham, a har is the hole in a stone in which the spindle of a gate rests.

Hec cera,
Hec serula, a lok.

Hic clatrus, a barre.
Cardo sus est foribus si cardonis sit generalis,
Et si cardonis est herba nociva colonis,
Cardonis est herba multum fullonibus apta.

Hec clavis
Hec clavicula, a key.
Hic clavus, a naylle. Clava ferit, clavis aperit, clavus duo jungit.
Hoc pessulum, a snek. Snek, a latch of a door.
Hic vectis, a slott. Slot, the bolt of a door.

ITEM.HI: Hec grapa, est foramen in quo quies∣cit vectis.

LIST.ITEM: Hic clitorium, a clekyt. Clekyt, a cliket, or latch-key.
Hic cava, a guttyr in the herthe.
Hec fistula, est instrumentum in quo aqua currit. Arbor aqueductus est fistula, musica, morbus.

Hoc aquaductum,
Hoc guttarium,
Hoc aqueductile, a guttur.
Hic aqueductus, a cundyth undyr the erthe.
Hec barcaria, i. ovile, a schepcott.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA VESTIMENTORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec acupicta, a jak of fens.
Hec tribrica, the strapuls of a pare brek.

ITEM.HI: Hoc colobium, i. vestis collobia par∣vula dena.

LIST.ITEM: Hec lucina, a gore. Gore, a hem, or gusset. In Walter de Biblesworth, it is given as the interpre∣tation of the Anglo-Norman or French geroun.

Hoc stropheum,
Hec zona, a gyrdylle. Zona dic stropheum, palmam dic esse tropheum.
Hoc cimicinctum, a saynt of sylk.
Hoc mercipium, a pawtnere. Pawtnere, a purse.

Hoc acumen,
Hec acies, a neg.
Hec spirula, a vyrille. Vyrille, a gimlet, or wimble.

Hoc tenaculum,
Hic spirasmus, a tang.
* * * * Unfortunately a leaf of the original MS. has been torn out here, making a rather extensive lacuna, as the manuscript is written in three columns.

ITEM.HI: Hic circius, est ventus borialis sub aquilonem versus occidentem.
Hic aquilo, septentris, ventus boralis, idem est; ventus aquilonaris est sibi conjunctus versus orientem; ventus collateralis est intermedius inter bariam et subsolanum.

LIST.ITEM: Hoc confragum, a plays where the whyrwynd metes.
Hoc bivium, a gaytschadyls. Cross-roads; the word signifles lite∣rally, a separation or divergence of roads; "gateschadylle, compitum," Prompt. Parv.
Hec limpha etiam idem est. Est aqua doctrina, populus, dolor, ac ele∣mentum.

Hoc mare,
Hic pelagus, the see.

Hoc flumen,
Hic fluvius, a flod.
Hic rivulus, a bek. A small brook; still in use in the north.

Hec fovea,
Hec fossa, a dyke.
Hic vel hec dies, a day.
Hoc saxifragium, a qwaryle. A quarry.
Hic collis, the top of a hylle.

Hic campus,
Hic rus, a feld.
Hoc columber, a arehole. i. e., an air-hole—a small unglazed window.

Hoc rete,
Hec plaga, a nett.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA LUDORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec acies, a scheltrone. The sheltron was a square, or divi∣sion of soldiers—a squadron.
Hec pirga, the poynt of the chekyre.

Hec cithera,
Hec lira, a harpe.
Hoc psalterium, idem est. Salterium dicitur organicum fore librum.

LIST.HEAD: DE VITE ET MATERIIS IPSIUS.
LIST.ITEM:
Hoc vitulamen est planta vite inf . . .
Et vitis radix, sunt fructus vin . . .
Pampinus est folium, botrus flos vin . .

ITEM.HI: Hec vinea, est locus ubique usitatus.

LIST.ITEM: Hic palmes, a brawnch of vyne.

ITEM.HI: Hoc sincetum, est ramus pretentus a vite.
Hic bubastus, est vitis vel uva in agro.

LIST.ITEM:
Hec uva,
Hec uvula, a grape.

ITEM.L: Dant uvapassa clibano simeraria plebe,
Uva precerra, vel precox tibi primatura, ubi preco
Quo quando vel precox tibi prematura sunt uva.

LIST.HEAD: DE CIBIS GENERALIBUS.
LIST.ITEM: Hic dapis, -pem, -pe, idem est. Nobilitas viles frons generosa dapes.

Hoc auncinium,
Hec imranda,
Hoc merarium, a myddyner undermete. A meal between the dinner and supper.
Hec cena, a sopere. A second supper, taken late in the evening.
Hec musta, idem est. Dic mustam cenam, mustumque latens odorem.
Hec dieta, est cibus moderatus, etc. Estque dieta cibus moderatus, iter quoque diei.

LIST.HEAD: DE PANIBUS ET PARTIBUS EORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec nebula, oblys. A small round loaf, as it is explained in the verse. Est nubis nebula tenuis panisque rotundus.
Hec lesca, a schyfe. Schyfe, or shive, a slice.
Hec colirida, a dorcake. Dor- cake. The collyrida was a sort of cracknell, or crisp cake, somewhat re∣sembling biscuit.

LIST.HEAD: DE SPECIEBUS LIGUMINIS.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec vita,
Hoc sepulatum, sew. Pottage.
Hoc amigdalatum, almundmylke. See before, p. 713, note 3.

Hoc puls,
Hec aplauda,
Hoc ferculum, a mese. Fercula nos saciant, prelatos fercula portant.
Hoc jurcellum, jursylle. Jussell was a favourite dish, composed of eggs and grated bread, boiled in broth, and seasoned with sage and saffron.
Hoc lattum, lorray. Lorray, or lorré, was a dish, in ancient cookery, for which receipts are found in most of the cookery books.
Hic garus, a fyscbrowe. Literally, broth of fish.
Hoc omlaccinium, charlyt. Charlet was a dish, in medieval cook∣ery, of which the principal ingredient was minced pork.

LIST.HEAD: DE CIBIS GENERALIBUS.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc crimium, crowkoun. Perhaps the dish called in the early treatises on cookery crayton, or criton—a preparation of chickens.
Hoc frixum, idem est. Frixa nocent, elixa juvant, assata cohercent.

ITEM.HI: Hic artocasius, cibus factus ex pane et casio.

LIST.ITEM:
Hee delicie,
Hec lauticia,
Hee galanticie, dantyths.

Hoc frixum, a froys. A froise was a sort of pancake. The word is still used in the dialect of the eastern countries. It appears to have been a favourite dish with the monks; for Gower (Conf. Amant., vol. ii., p. 92), de∣scribing the troubled sleep of Sompno∣lence, says—
Whan he is falle in suche a dreme,
Right as a ship ayein the streme
He routeth with a slepy noise,
And brustleth as a monkes froise,
Whan it is throwe into the panne.

Hoc strutum,
Hec tripa, a tripe.
Hec caro, -nis, man's flesche. Carnes carniflces, carnem vendunt mere∣trices.

Hec offa, a alesope.
Est crateris vipa, scutelle dicitur offa,
Sed limphe proprie dicitur ipa fore.

LIST.HEAD: DE LECTIS ET ORNAMENTIS EORUM.

ITEM.HI: Hoc grabatum, media producta, idem est.
ITEM.L: Est lectus stratum, fertur via regia strata;
Mobile fit stratus ad quod depressus habetur.

LIST.ITEM: Hic thorus, idem est. Dicas esse thoros, paliaria, brachia, lectos.

ITEM.HI: Hoc lectiferum, est lectus stratum vel locus ubi lectuli sternuntur, vel stramenta lectorum.
Hic genialis, est lectus qui in nup∣ciis sternitur.
Hec sponda, est exterior pars lecti.

ITEM.L: Cum soleas in eas caput inclinari gravatum,
Disce graba signare caput, venit inde gra∣batum.

ITEM.HI: Hec lectica, est lectus vel thorus, vel currus quod dicitur lectus, vel est curtina circa lectum.
Hee spinge, -arum, sunt lectuli in [quibus] sunt posite efigie.
Hic punicanus, est lectus circumclu∣sus tapicoleribus rubeis.

ITEM.L: Sit cooportorium lecto lecturaque crinis,
Sit tectorem domibus regimen cat sic verge.
Armaque craterras quoque simul capulas.

ITEM.HI: Hec amphicapa, est tapeta ex utra∣que parte villosa.

ITEM.L: Amphicapam dicas gemma de parte villosa,
Sicut historiis simplex est sipha trapeta.

ITEM.HI: Hoc subsiterium, est tapetum sub pe∣ditali.

LIST.ITEM: Hec curtina, a curtyn. Dicas curtinas quasi rerum corda tenentes;

ITEM.HI: . . . repium recium texta ad ar∣dendos culices et muscas.

LIST.ITEM: Hoc auriale, a cord or a pelowe.

Hoc pulviner,
Hoc cervicarium,
Hic pulvinus, a coschyn.

ITEM.HI: est po . . . ex line et lana contextus.

DIV2.HEAD: XX. A PICTORIAL VOCABULARY. This very curious vocabulary is pre∣served in a manuscript in the possession of Lord Londesborough, which I think is of the latter part of the fifteenth century. The illustrative sketches, which occupy the margins and what would have been other∣wise blank places in the manuscript, are here given, with the inscriptions attached, of the same size, and as nearly as possible facsimilies, of the original. (OF THE FIFTEENTH CENTURY.)

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA HUMANO CORPORI.
LIST.ITEM: Hoc occiput, Ance the last parte of the hede.
Hoc interciput, Ance the myd parte of the hede.
Hic vertex, Ance a natrelle. The hatrelle.
Hoc discrimen, Ance the sced of the hede. Sit tibi discrimen divisio, glabra, periclum.

Hic crinis,
Hic pilus,
Hic capillus,
Hec coma,
Hec sesaries, idem sunt, Ance a here.
Sesaries hominum, sed crines sunt mulie∣rum;
Hujus vel illius bene dicitur esse capillus.

Hec maxilla,
Hec mala,
Hec gena, idem sunt, a scheke.
Hic ffrons, -dis, Ance brawnche. Frons, -dis, ramus, frons, -tis, pars capi∣talis.
Hoc cilium, Ance a here of the hie.

Hec bucca,
Hec ffaux, Ance a scheke.
Ad navem malus spectat, malus est viciosus,
Faux est mala, malum vicium, malum quo∣que pomum.
Hoc intercilium, Ance betwyn the browes.
Hec pupilla, Ance the balle of the ye.

Hec abbcies,
Hec abbedo, Ance the qwyt of the ye.
Hoc interficium, Ance the bryd of the ne.
Hec piruela, Ance the cop of the no . . .
Hic cirrus, Ace the cop of the hede.
Hic polipus, idem. Polupus est naris fetor, et in equore piscis.

Hec barba,
Hoc genorbidum, a berd.
Hoc os, ossis, Ace a bone.
Hoc os, -ris, Ace a mowth. Os, oris, loquitur, corio vestitur os, ossis.
Hec glossa, idem est. Est membrum lingua, designat et hec igonis.
Hoc labium, Ace a lyp super os.

FIGURE.FIGDESC: a portrait of a human, a heart pierced by an arrow, a four-leafed clover shape

LIST.ITEM:
Hec auris,
Hec auricula, a ere.
Hoc tolera, Colera. See before, p. 676 l. 9. Ace a eresop.
Hic molaris, idem est. Ventes molares, lapides dic esse molares.
Hec veruca, Ace a worthe. Wrothe. A wart is still called a wrat in some of the northern dialects.

Hec gula,
Hoc guttur,
Hic jugulus, a throthe. Est gula pars colli, victum gula restat edendi.
Hoc pupillum, the blak of the ye.

Hoc bachium,
Hic lacertus,
Hec ulna, a harmehole. Brachia die ulnas, panni mensura sit ulua.

Hic vultus, -tus, -ui, Ace a schere. The word schere, in the sense of countenance or mien, is not a very com∣mon word, but it occurs more than once in the romances of Gawayne, edited for the Roxburgh Club by Sir Frederick Madden.

Hec spina,
Hoc spondile, a rygbone.
Hec spina, Ace a thorne. Me pungit spina, pars est in corpore spina.

Hic ricus, -cus, -ui, Ace the nest of the ye.
Hic ricus per -ci peculas fera dicimus esse.
Hic ricus dans -ui pars ultima constat ocelli.
Hec arteria, Ace the hole of the throt.
Hec uva, Ace the knot of the nek. Opptulio os uvam, fert vitis fertilis nvam.

Hec palma,
Hoc ir,
Hec vola, the palme of the hand. Palma manus, palma arbor, victoria palma.
Hic articulus, Ace a too. Est manuum digitus, articulusque pedum.
Hoc fren, Ace the sekyn of the brayne.
Hic allux, Ace a grete too. Est manuum polles, sed dicatur pedis allux.
Hec unguis, Ace a nayle of a man.
Hec ungula, Ace a claw of a best. Unguis non brutis datur, sed ungula brutis.
Hoc tergum, Ace a hak of a man.

Hoc tergus,
Hoc dorsum, a bak of a best.

Hic venter,
Hoc uterus,
Hic alvus, a wombe.
Hic vel hec clunis, Ace a hepebone.
Hec mamilla, Ace a lytyl pap.
Hec mamma, Ace a pap of a woman.

Hoc uber, Ace a pap of a best.
Nos hominum proprie mamillas dicimus esse,
Ubera et pecudum, sed mamme et mulie∣rum;
Cuins mamillas dixisti, dicque patillas.
Hec costa, Ace a baksterys slomb. Pars lateris costa, res pistoris quoque costa.

Hec pubes,
Hic lanugo,
Hoc pecten, Ance schere.

Hoc femur,
Hoc crus, a they.
Hec caturda, Caturda was used in the Latin of the fifteenth century to indicate a part of the female sexual organs, either the labia pu∣dendi, or the nymphae. Ace a bobrelle.

FIGURE.HEAD: a man{us}

LIST.ITEM:
Hec munda,
Hec matrix,
Hec steria, a schyn that a schyld ys consevyd in.
Hoc extum Ace a gret paugh.
Hec struta, Ace a startere of nete.

Hoc intestinum
Hic colus, a nestarme.

Hoc epar, -ris, Ace the lywer.
Cor sapit, et pulmo loquitur, fel coligit iram,
Splen ridere facit, cogit amare jecur.

Hec pinguedo, Ace fatnes.
Erba sit hec fragus, hoc fragrum sit tibi fructus,
Hic fragrus, -gi, pomplex cernatur haberi.
Hic talus, Ace a dyse. Ludo cum talis, terram tango quoque talis.

Hic sanguis,
Hic cruor, Ance blode.
Sanguis alit corpus, cruor est a corpore sumptus; a leg
Extractus venis cruor est, in corpore san∣guis.
Hoc sperma, -tis, Ace mankynd. Semen quod seritur, set progenies quoque sperma.
Hoc alatum, Ace a rofom. Rofom. In the Devonshire dialect the waist is called rofoam.

Hoc stercus,
Hec meda, a torde.

Hoc internodium,
Hoc vertebrum, a knebone.
Hec tibea, Ace a trompe. Tibia dat sonitum, me portat tibia totum.
Hic poder, Ace the fylthe of the fothe.

Hic callus,
Hec planta, Ance the harde of the fothe. Signat callus plantam collumque bovinum.
Hec arcacis, Ace slepe of the fothe. Pes patitur artare, Ance my fothe ys a slepe.
Hoc apostema, -tis, Ace a postemet. An aposteme, or abscess.
Hec vola, Ace the holle of the fothe. Est vola pars palme, pars ale, pars pedis una.
Hic index, Ace a lykpot. The second cut at the bottom of this page, representing a hand, sword, and head, are drawn upside-down in the original, as here shown.

FIGURE.FIGDESC: a hand holding a sword cutting off a head

LIST.ITEM:
Hic auricularis, Ace the lythylman. These popular names of the fingers seem to be of considerable antiquity. The following curious lines are quoted by Mr. Halliwell (Dict of Arch. Words) from a MS. of the fifteenth century in the Uni∣versity Library, Cambridge (Ff. v. 48, fol. 83):
Ilke a fyngir has a name, als men thaire fyngers calle.
The lest fyngir hat lityl-man, for hit is lest of alle;
The next fynger hat leche-man, for quen a leche dos ogt,
With that fynger he tastes all thyng how that hit is wrogt;
Long-man hat the mydilmast, for longest fynger hit is;
The ferthe men calls towcher, therwith men touches i-wis;
The fifte fynger is the thowmbe, and hit has most mygt,
And fastest haldes of alle the tother, forthi men calles hit rigt.
A Nominale in MS. Reg 17, C. XVII., fol. 39, ro, gives the following list, very similar to that in our text:
Hic pollex, Ae thowme.
Hic index, Ae lic-pote.
Hic medius, Ae lang-fynger.
Hic medicus, Ae leche
Hic auricularis, Ae lytyl-fynger.
Mr. Halliwell has printed a modern nurs∣ery rhyme, (Nursery Rhymes of England, fifth edition, p. 155), in which names very similar to these are still used, namely, thumbkin, foreman, longman, ringman, and littleman. In Norfolk the fingers are called popularly, Tom - thumbkin, Will∣wilkin, Long-gracious, Betty bodkin, Little∣tit. Pollex, index, medius, medicus, auricularis.
Hic musculus, Ace a lytyl mus. Est musculus piscis, parvus mus, pars tibiales.
Hec solia, Ace the sole of the fote.
Hoc solium, Ace a kynges sete. Sub pede sit solia, solium quoque regia sedes.

Hoc altare,

Hec fiola,
Hic urcius, a cruet.

Hec osta,

Hec aserra, a schyp that zychel ere in.

Hoc thus,
Hoc incesum, Ance ensence.
Hic mergulus, Ace herne in the lamp.

Hoc candelebrum,
Hoc candelarium, a candyllestyk.

Hoc vestiarium,
Hoc vestibulum, a vestri.

Hec leges,
Hec legenda,

Hec letenia,
Hec laturia, a letenyboke.

Hec zona,
Hoc tropheum, a gyrdylle.

Hic gradus, -dus, -ui, Ace a grese. A step. In the directions in the will of Henry VI., for the building of the col∣leges at Eton and Cambridge, we read, "Item, the height fro the streete to the enhancing of the ground of the cemetery, 7 feete di., and the same walle in height above that, 5 feete di., with greeces out of the way into the same pane, as many as shalle be convenient."—"And from the provostes stalle unto the greece called Gradus Chori, 90 feete," &c.

Hoc pixis,
Hoc alabastrum, Ace a box.

Hec campana,
Hec campanicula, a belle.

Hoc fferetrum,
Hoc sandapulum,
Hec libetina,
Hic loculus, Ance a bere. Est loculus bursa, parvus locus, et lubitina.

Hoc vitrum,
Hoc ilum, Ance glas.

Hoc manutergium,
Hic towalus, a hand-clothe.

Hic certofagus,
Hoc sepulcrum,
Hoc bustum, Ance a grafe.

Hoc tumba,
Hoc monumentum, Ance a tumb.
Hoc poliandrum, Ace a byryelston. Byriel, or byriels, was the old name for a tomb.

Hoc mausolium,
Hic tumulus, Ance a grafe.

Hec corda,

Hec lanterna,

Hic asinus,
Hec asina, a has.

Hec vacca,

Hic bucculus,

Hec buccula,
Hec juvenca, a hekfere.
Hec ovis, alle manner a chepe.
Hic equiferus, Ace a wyld hors.

Hic porcus,

Hic edus,
Hic capriolus,
Hic edulus, a kyd lomb.

Hic catus,
Hic mureligus,
Hic pilax, a catt.
Hic catellus, Ace a cytlyng. A kitten.
Hic bubalus, Ace a bogelle. Bogelle, a beagle.

Hic sirogrillus,
Hic scurellus, a scurelle.
Hic vel hec talpa, Ace a molle.

Hic castor,

Hic taxus, a brok.

Hec crista.

Hic signus,

Hec alauda,
Hec antelucana,

Hic vespertilio,

Hec monedula,

Hic garulus,

Hic maviscus,

Hic ornix.

Hec vola, a parte of the harmehole.

Hic echinus,

Hec frisgula, Ace a chevender. Chevender, the cheven, or chub.

Hec epimera, -e,

Hoc allec,

Hec rugella,
Hoc rustiforum, a hornkeke. Horn-keck appears in Palsgrave as the name of a fish, which is said to be called also a greenback.

Hic idrus,

Hic biceps,

Hic cacadillus,

Hec formica,
Hec murunca, a pysmere.

Hec sanguifica,
Hec irudo, a leche.

Hec limax
Hec testudo, a snayle.

Hic tarinus
Hic simax, a maked. Maked, a maggot.
