Hec musca, Ace a fflye, alle maner.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA MUSCA∣RUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic siniflex, Ance a red fflye.

Hec polumita, Ace a bude. Bude, the weevil, a small insect of the beetle tribe which is destructive to grain. Tusser, as quoted by Halliwell, speaks of "bowd-eaten malt;" and the word is still preserved in the dialect of the eastern counties.
Hic stabo, Ace a scarbude. Scarbude, or scarnbude, a kind of beetle.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ME∣TALLORUM.

FIGURE.FIGDESC: a piece of metal held by tongs
FIGURE.HEAD: metallo

LIST.ITEM: Hoc stangnum, Ace a pond. Est aqua stans arte stagnum, stanuum die esse metallum.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA LAPI∣DUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hic lapis,
Hec petra,
Hoc saxum, a stonne.
Hic et hec silex, Ace a flyntstone.
Hic scripulus, Ace a lytyl stone.
Hec Margareta, a maydyn. Margarita lapis, sed Margareta puella.
Hec gemma, Ace a prceius stone.
Hic stupelus, Ace a precius stonne.
Hic rupes, Ace a roche of stone.
Hec pumes, Ace a nedyrstonne. The adder-stone.
Hic jacinctus, Ace a precius stone.

Hic gagates,
Hec smaragdus, a ruby.

Hec magdalena, a balwyn. Perhaps the baleis, a sort of ruby. It seems to be the same word as balayn in the following passage from the metrical romance of Richard Coer-de-Lion, l. 2979.
Her baner whyt, withouten fable,
With thre Sarezynes hedes off sable,
That wer schapen noble and large
Off balayn, both scheeld and targe.
Hic egipsum, Ace a egypstone. Probably gypsum.
Hic calculus, a ston in a mannys bleder.
Hic cals, Ace a parte of the fote. Pars pedis est hic cals, lapis ustus dicitur hec cals.
Hic petro, a chyp of a stone.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINEN∣CIA COQUINE.
LIST.ITEM: Hic cocus, alle maner a cokys.
Hic lixa, a swyllere. A scullion, one who swills the dishes.
Hic dapifer, a berere of mete.
Hic tripes, a brenlede. The brandlet, or brandreth. Cf. p. 660 l. 31.

Hic cacabus,
Hic lebes,
Hoc caduum, a cawdurne.
Hic urcius, Ace a bras pot.

Hec sartago,
Hoc fricsorium, a fryyngpan.

Hic cratus,
Hec craticula, a rostyngyryn.

Hec criagra,
Hec tridex, a flechehoke.
Hoc spumatorium, a schomore. i. e., a skummer.

Hec laxis,
Hec aspiculna, a sclys. Sclys, a slice, or implement for turn∣ing meat in the frying-pan.
Hoc calafactorium, a schasure. Sckasure, or shasor, a wine-cooler.

Hoc tribulum,
Hec pila, a pestelle.
Hic fractillus, a rage. In Somersetshire, a broken pan is still called a rage.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA BOTULARIE.
LIST.ITEM:
Hoc onafrum,
Hic uter, -ris,
Hec olla, a flaget. A flask, a leathern bottle.
Hec lura, a mowth of a flaget.
Hec lura, a nek of a flaget. Lura sit os utris, et collum luridus inde.

Hic crater,
Hec cateria, Ance a pese. Pece, or pese, was a common name for a drinking-cup.
Hec urnula, a not. Not, or nut, a sort of small vase.
Hic canterus, a colok. Collock is the name given in the north∣ern dialects to a large pail.
Hoc ciromellum, Ace growte. See before, p. 725 l. 27.
Hoc nectar, Ace piment. See before.
Hec amurca, a lyf of wyn.

FIGURE.HEAD: a pa¦nis The little figure at the head of this article is curious, as showing the usual form of the loaf of bread at this period.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA PANATRIE.
LIST.ITEM: Hec quadra, a cantel of brede.

Hec lesca,
Hec colirida, a schefe of brede.

Hic bolus,
Hic murcellus,
Hec buccella, a musselle. i. e., a morsel. Est buccella cibus quantum semel accipis ore.

Hoc salinum,
Hoc assitabulum, a salere.

Hoc gausape,
Hoc toral,
Hec mappa, a burdclothe.
Hec culingna, Ace a line∣shark. Lineshark. Culigna, in good Latin, signified a drinking bowl.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA VESTIMEN∣TORUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec vestis
Hoc vestimentum,
Hoc indumentum, Ace clothe.
Hoc superum, Ance a pryn. Pryn, a woman's smock.
Hoc pelicium, Ace a pylchen. A furred outer-coat.

Hoc mantile,
Hoc mantellum, a mantelle.
Hec tena, Ace a hewd. Hewd, the extremity of the riband hanging from the bishop's mitre.

Hec toga,
Hoc epitogium, a gowyn.

Hec camisia,
Hec subuncula, a scherte.

Hec supera,
Hec instita, a rokete or a lyste.
Hec lombesina, Ance a paltoke. A paltock was a doublet or cloak descending to the middle of the thigh. It is a word which has recently been brought into use again.

He bracce, -arum,
Hoc ffemorale,
Hoc perizoma, Ance a breke.
Hoc subligar, Ace a styltbonde. Subliger est legula caligas quas sublygans alte.
Hec ffirotica, Ace a glofe. For cirotica, i. e. chirotheca. It is another example of the curious use of the f, remarked in a former note.

Hic ffractillus, Ace a dag of a gowyn. The dagging, jagging, or foliating, the edges of garments, came into fashion apparently in the reign of Edward III., and prevailed more or less till the latter part of the fifteenth century.

FIGURE.FIGDESC: an animal, a portrait of a man, a fish, a bird

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PERTINENCIA CAMERE.
LIST.ITEM:
Hic camrius,
Hic et hec sinista, Ance a scham∣berleyne.
Hoc lectum, alle maner off beddys.
Hoc grabatum, a seke mannys beddys.
Hoc torum, Ace a husbondes bedde
Hec toreuma, Ace a kynges bedde.

Hoc supralectum,
Hec tectora, a selowyr. The celure, of roof, of the bed.
Hoc capisterium, Ace a redele. The ridel, or bed-curtain.
Hoc tapetum, Ace a schalun. See before, p. 626, note 2.
Hoc torall, idem est. Est toral mappa, tegmen lectoque vocatur.

Hec coma,
Hoc pecten, a combe.
Hoc caliandrum, a wulpere. Wulpere. The Latin word caliendrum signifies false hair—a periwig. A wul∣pere was perhaps a head-dress composed of false hair; probably the same word as volupere.
Hoc anabatum, Ace a docer addorsum.

Hec fforma,
Hoc schabellum, a forme.
Hoc utensule, howseho. Househo. Perhaps this singular word signifies a chamber-pot.
Hoc stramentum, lyttere. Litter, the straw with which the bed was formerly made.

Hic stratus, -tus, -ui,
Hoc stratum, -ti, -to, a bed. Stratus vel -tum confinguntur tibi lectum.
Hoc epicausterium, a thuelle. The pipe of the chimney.

Hic caminus, a chymny.
Emittens fumum tibi sit locus ipse caminus,
Maximus atque rogus tibi dicitur esse ca∣minus.

LIST.HEAD: PARTES DOMUS.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec paries, -tis,
Hic murus, a walle.
Hoc festum, a holyday. Pars festum tecti et dicitur esse solenne.
Hoc sigillum, a barer of a rofetre.
Hoc lucanar, a day of a wyndow. Otherwise called a bay of a window, the space between the mullions.
Hoc superuminare, Ace a lenterne. The lantern, or light from above.
Hoc manutentum Ance a haginday. A sort of wooden latch for a door is still called a haggeday in Yorkshire.
Hic gumser, Ance a hengylle. A hengle, or hinge.
Hec area, Ance a florthe. i. e., a floor.

ITEM.HI: Hec capedo, dicitur spacium inter parietes.

LIST.ITEM: Hic ffocus, Ance a fyir. Est altare focus, locus et focus ignis.
Hic stilus, Ace a smal of a pelyr.

Hec ffornix,
Hic arcus, Ance a . . .

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ECCLESIASTICORUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hic papa, Ace a pape. This word had been nearly erased in the MS., no doubt after the Reformation. It is a curious example of the extent to which the order for erasing the pope's name from public documents was carried out.

Hic canselarius,
Hic scriba, a scawnceler.

Hic presbeter,
Hic et hec sacerdos,
Hic capellanus, a pryst.
Sacris dicatus vel sacris deditus atque
Sacra dans, vel dux sacer esto sacerdos.

Hic diaconus,
Hic levita, a dekyn.
Hic et hec secrista, a sekyrsteyn.

Hic doctor,
Hic instructor,
Hic monitor,
Hic petegogus,
Hic auctor,
Hic imbutor,
Hic papas,
Hic didasculus,
Hic magister, -ri, -ro, a mayster.
Doctor et instructor, monitor, petegogus, et auctor,
Imbutor, papas, didasculus, atque magister.

Hic dioleticus,
Hic arcista, a arcister.
Hic teolagus, a mayster of divinite.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA DOMINORUM TEMPORALIUM.

ITEM.L: Legis est certum clerique corona poete,
Aurea rex gestat diadema vel induperator.

LIST.ITEM: Hic barunculus, a baronet. i. e., a lesser or minor baron. Our modern title of baronet of course came in at a much later period.

Hoc corrodium,
Hec armilla, a levery.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA AR∣MORUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec arma,
Hec arma∣tura, a we∣pyn.
Hec galea, media producta, a galle.
Hec galea, media corrupta, a helme. Induo me galea, galeatus duco galeam.
Hec bombecina, a acton. The acketoun, or acton, was a sort of tunic worn under the coat of mail.

Hic tassis, a nett. a spear piercing a heart
a cor
a lancea
Hec tassis galea, hic tassis rethia monstrat.
Hec larva, Ace a dewylle. i. e., a devil, or demon; a hobgoblin.
Hec larva, Ace a selerelle. This means apparently a scarecrow. Larva fugit volucres, faciem tegit, est quo∣que demon.
Hec femoralia, Ace a quischens. More usually called cuisses, the pieces of armour which protected the thighs.
Hic anceps, Ace a towhand swerd.
Hec gesa, Ace a gysyryne. See before, p. 653 1. 29. Non amat ille Jhesum qui fert ad prelia gesam.
Hec spata, Ace a pleyend swerd.
Hec clava, Ace a mase. Clava ferit, clavis aperit, clavus duo jungit.
Hec ffudes, Sic, for sudes. a pikestafe. Fustes fetate poterint sudes bene dici.
Hic baculus, Ace alle maner stavis.

Hoc scutum,
Hoc cliphium, a buccler.
Hec petrima, Ance a gune. This is the first occurrence of the gun among weapons in these vocabularies.

Hoc telum,
Hoc pilum, a darte.
Hec tela, -e, Ance a webe. Nos vestit tela, volitant per prelia tela.

Hoc mustile,
Hoc jaculum, a darte.
Hec sestus, Ace a pavis. The pavis was a large shield.
Hec ffalaa, Ace a lumpe of a walle.
Hoc propinaculum, Ace a bretayge. The bretasche, or parapet.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA BLADO∣RUM ET ARBO∣RUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec seges,
Hoc satum,
Hoc bladum,
Hoc granum,
Hoc fruges,
Hic messis, corne.
Dum seritur seges, sata dum radisibus herent,
Blada virore virent, granaria grana reser∣vant;
Fruges dum fruimur, sunt messes quando metuntur.
Hoc essaticum, Ance bere. Bere, a kind of barley.

Hec siligo,
Hoc ergalum, Ance rye.
Hec viscia, Ace a feche. i. e., a vetch.

Hec avicula, Ace wyld hote.
Radix, festuca, conculnio, nodus, arista,
Granum cum palia fer sufficit sit quoque scripta,
Sunt partes messis firma tellure manentes.

Hec garba,
Hec merges,
Hec gelima, Ace a schefe.
Hec congelima, Ance a schokke. A shock, at the present day in the north, is twelve sheaves of corn.
Hec borago, -nis, Ace broges. Broges, i. e. borage.
Porri vel sepe fertur bulbus capud esse.

Hic sinolus,
Hec sipula, a schybbolle. A chibbal, or small onion.
Hec malvia, Ance a hok. The holyhock.
Hec lancea, Ance a robworte. Perhaps the plant adders tongue, called in Latin lancea Christi.
Hec ebula Ace a wallewurte. Wall-wort.
Hic papillus, Ace a heyoffe. Hayhofe, or ground-ivy.
Hec eruca, Ace a schynlok. Rocket, the reseda of botanists.
Hec zizania, Ance a drawke. This word is still preserved in the dialects of the Eastern counties, where it is applied to a plant resembling darnell.
Hec samina, Ance a saveryn. Perhaps the savin-tree (juniperus sa∣bina).
Hoc jurbarium, Ance a silfgrene. The houseleek.
Hec menoloca, Ance a bothun. A button, or bud?
Hec locusta, Ance a sokylblome. Sokyl-blome, perhaps the honey-suckle.

Hec arundo, -nis,
Hec canna, a redde.
Hec rapa, Ance a neppe. Catmint, or nep (nepeta cataria).
Hec conseria, Ance a wyld fr . . .
Hoc morsuspoli, a schykynw . . . i. e., chicken-wort.
Hec lentige, a nedmet. Nedmete, perhaps the lentil, a small kind of pulse.
Hec eufrasia, Ance a heufrasy . . . Eyebright (euphrasia officinalis).

Hoc lollium,
Hoc git, indeclinabile, Ance kokylle.
Hoc cirpillum, Ance a pellek. Pellek, a name for wild-thyme, or, as it is popularly called in some parts, ladies' bedstraw.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ESSCARUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hoc prandium,
Hoc epulum, Ance mete.

Hic cibus,
Hec esca,
Hec daps, Ance mete.

Hic victus, -tus, -tui,
Hoc victuale, Ance lyfefode.

Hoc pulmentorium, Ance a pulment.
Est cibus et semen pulmentum dicitur esse,
At cibus quidem sunt pulmentaria dicta.
Hoc edulium, Ance sowylle. See before, p. 661 l. 9.
Hec placencia, Ance a payman. i. e., painmain. See before, p. 657 l. 26.

Hoc labum,
Hoc libellum, a wa∣stelle.

Hicpanis subverucius, a meleres cake. A miller's cake. Perhaps this name alludes to the common report that the miller always stole the flour from his customers to make his cakes, which were baked on the sly. See The Reve's Tale in Chaucer.

Hec nebula.
Hec gafra, a wafrun.
Hoc calenum, Ance a ffyrmele. Fyrmele, perhaps frumity, or furmity.
Hoc vitalium, Ance charlett. A dish made of minced pork.

Hoc legumen,
Hoc puls, Ance potage.
Hec carbonella, Ance a colepe. A collop, or slice of meat, or rasher of bacon, broiled.
Hoc consisum, Ance alle maner sew.
Hoc omentum, Ance a womclotte. The wombclout was properly the caul which envelopes the intestines.

Hoc extum,
Hoc esmum, Ance a trype.
Hoc fferculum, a salt stole. Fercula nos faciant, prelatos fercula portant.

Hoc fertum,
Hoc omasum,
Hoc tucetum, Ance a podyng.
Hec ulla, Ance a sawsyrlyng. A sausage.
Hec assa, Ance a rost mete.

Hoc lactatum,
Hoc balductum, Ance a poset.
Hec perna, Ance a flyk of bacun.
Hoc albumen, Ance the whyte of the hey.
Tres partes ovi, albumen, testa, vitellus.
Hec pulpá, Ance the brawn of a bore.
Hec arula, Ance a croke. Arula is explained in the Anglo-Saxon vocabularies as meaning a fire-pan, or vessel for holding lighted charcoal. Tolle peripsima, post pete pulpam, disper∣nis arulam.

Hoc sinapium, Ance mustarde.
Salgia, sirpillum, piper, alia, sal, petro∣cillum,
Ex hiis sit salsa, non est sentencia falsa.

FIGURE.FIGDESC: a portrait of a human with bones
FIGURE.HEAD: Infirmitatū

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA INFIRMITATUM.
LIST.ITEM: Hec impetigo, Ance a tesyng. An old name for a ring-worm.
Hic tussis, Ance the cowe. Cowe, a cough. This shows the old way of pronouncing the word.
Hec extecis, -ce, Ance a scunnyng. A disease of the heart.
Hic catarus, Ance a pore. A pose, or cold in the head.
Nominativo clunucus, -ca, -cum, Ace berede. Berede, perhaps bed-rid.
Hec squacia, Ance a queynose. The quinsy.
Hec antrax, Ance a felun bleyn. A whitlow.
Hec paucitas, Ance a cattes here. Huloet has, "Cattes-heere, otherwyse called a felon, furunculus."
Hic morbus caducus, the fallyn evylle.
Hic mutulatus, Ance a mayn. i. e., a maim.

Hoc vulnus,
Hec plaga, a wonde.
Hic sicatrix, Ance a old wownde.
Hec peruda, Ance a keybe hele.
Hec vibex, Ance a strype. Strype. The Nomenclator, a vocabulary printed in 1585, explains vibex by "the marke of a blowe or stripe remaining in the fleshe blacke and blewe."

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA MULIERUM CUM SUIS INSTRUMENTIS.
LIST.ITEM: Hec domina, Ance alle maner lady.

Hec fflammia,
Hoc flamiolum, a cherchow. A kerchief.
Hec tricatura, Ance a tresewyr. The tressure, or arrangement of the hair.

Hec presbeterissa,
Hec sacerdotissa, a prystes wyfe.
Hic sacerdotulus, Ance a prestes sun.
Hec sacerdotula, Ance a prestes dowtyr.

Hec uxor,
Hec sponsa, a wyfe.

Hec femina,
Hec mulier, a woman.

FIGURE.HEAD: a asi{us} The inscription to this diagram is written at the edge of the paper and partly lost, but it was evidently casius, i. e., cheese.

LIST.ITEM: Hoc mulsum, Ance the wyte of botyr.
Hoc serum, Ance the whey of chese. Sit liquor hoc serum, defundat casius ipsum.
Hoc tolustrum, Ance besning. Besning, the first milk, now called the beastings. The Latin word should be co∣lustrum.

Hec balducta,
Hoc coagulum, a crud or a posset.
Hoc occigalum, Ance a sowyr mylke.
Hoc valatorium, Ance a scharne. A churn.
Hoc multrale, Ance the tyn of the mylke. i. e., a milk-can.
Hec armifodrita, Ance a scrate. A hermaphrodite. See before, p. 695 l. 2.

Hec mater,
Hec genetrix, a modyr.

Hec mammus,
Hec mamillo,
Hoc uber, -ris, Ance pappe.
Hoc vertebrum, Ance a aworowylle. A whirle, or round piece of wood put on the spindle of the spinning-wheel.

Hoc alabrum,
Hoc traale, -is, Ance a rele.
Hec glomeracio, a hep of threde.
Hec congeries, Ance a hep of stonys. Congeries lapidum tibi sit, glomeracio fili.
Hoc locium, Ance ley and nettyng.
Hoc smigma, -tis, Ance a soppe. i. e., soap.
Hoc stigma, Ance the dere yn a man∣nys hede. A mark of disgrace, by burning, &c. on the head. Smigma capud mundat, stigma dolore gra∣vat.

Hec feratorium,
Hoc pecten, a batylledore.
Hec excudia, Ance a sungyllestok. A swingle-stock, a wooden implement for beating flax or hemp, to separate the outer coating from the fibre. Swingle-hand is another name for the same implement.
Hoc rupeste, a repyllestok. Repylle-stok, an implement for clean∣ing flax.
Hoc asperum, Ance a top of lyne.
Hic limphus, a stryke of lyne.
Hec pronuba, a bawstrop. See before, p. 695 l. 18.
Hec pectrix, -cis, a cemster. A female who combs, a kembster.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA TERRARUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec terra, -e,
Hec ruus, -i,
Hoc arvum, -i,
Hoc campum, -i, Ance the fyld. a road and a hill
a via
a mons
Arvum, campus, ager, rus, sic diversificatur;
Dum seritur sit ager, et semen conditur illo;
Campus dicatur dum fructibus expoliatur;
Messibus est arvum tectum flore vel erbis,
Incultum rus est, veluti sunt pascua silve.
Hec acra, Ance a akyr lond.
Hec virgata, Ance a eryd lond.
Hic selis, -is, Ance a ryggyd lond.

Hic sulcus,
Hec lira, a fforow.
Hec amsages, Ance a but of lond.

Hoc archifenium,
Hoc croftum, a crofe.
Hec collis, Ance a lytylle hylle.

Hoc montanum,
Hic alpes, a grete hylle.
Distant montana sic, alpes, collis, et agger;
Designant magnum cumulum terre duo prima,
Alteria bina notant parvum cumulum quo∣que terre.

Hec trama,
Hec orbita,
Hec semita, Ance a paytt. Trama parva via tibi sit tranversa per arvum.
Hec specula, a totynghylle. To tote was to spy, or watch. A toting-hill would be a mound, or hill, in a prominent position, raised or occupied for watching.

Hoc fimarium,
Hoc sterculinium, a muckelle. A muck-hill, or dunghill.

Hoc argillum,
Hec argilla, Ance clay.
Hic linus, Ance a sclott. Sclott. Sticky clay is still called slot in Lincolnshire.
Hic et hec mergo, idem est. Fontis mergo, maris litus, sic ripa fluentis.
Hoc cosidium, Ance a torsy. Torsy. Perhaps this is a blunder for corsy, and means a causeway.

Hec lapifodina,
Hoc saccifragium, a stonquarelle.
Hec insula, Ance a hylyn of the see.
Hec cateracta, Ance a wey of hewyn.
Hec cateracta, Ance a wyndowe. Est cateracta via dicitur celique fenistra.

Hic bivius,
Hic trivius,
Hic quatrivius a gateschedelle.

He spelunca,
Hec caverna,
Hec cripa, a denne.
Hoc volutabrum, Ance a selot. Volutabrum is explained in the No∣menclator, "A wallowing place for cattell, bores, and swine." A wide ditch is still called a slot in Devonshire.
Hic et hec et hoc specus, Ance a wel∣bryng. Welbryng. This word, to judge by the Latin equivalent, must mean a cave.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA AQUARUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hoc mare,
Hoc pelagus,
Hoc equor, Ance the see.

Hec aqua,
Hec latex,
Hec limpha,
Hec unda, Ance water.
Hec aqua, Ance folke. Est aqua qua fruimur doctrina, dolor, po∣pulusque.

Hec fossa,
Hec fovia,
Hec cavea,
Hec antra, Ance a dyke.

Hec scatebra,
Hec scatarigo, a sprynge.
Hec lacuna, Ance a playche of water.
Hoc vadum, Ance a wadth. i. e., a place you can wade through, a ford.

Hic gurges, -tis,
Hoc rudor,
Hec rudor, a gotyr.
Hoc meandrum, Ance a stynkyng pytt.

Hec stilla,
Hec gutta, a drope.
Hec ledonis, Ance a sulse. Sulse, the flow of the sea-tide.
Hic cataclismus, Ance helle, ut patet per versus. Designant tibi delivium, baratrique pro∣fundum.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA PLANETORUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hoc celum,
Hic polus, Ance hewyn.

Hic sol,
Hic phebus, Ance the sunne.
Hic clipsis, the clyppes of the sunne.

Hec luna,
Hec phebe, Ance the mone.

Hic aier,
Hec aera,
Hic ether,
Hec ethera, the wethyr.

Hic ventus,
Hec aura, the wynde.

Hec nubes,
Hoc nubulum,
Hec nubula, a clowde.

Hec stella,
Hoc astrum,
Hoc sidus,
Hic canis, Ance alle maner sterres.

Hec septimana,
Hec ebdomeda, Ance a weke.
Hic vel hec dies, -ei, Ance a day.

Hoc crepusculum,
Hoc vesper, -eris, a hewyntyde.

Hic rogus,
Hic ignis,
Hic focus, Ance fyre.

Hic iems,
Hec bruma, Ance wynter.
Hec ira, Ance wrethe. Iris res mira, sed non est iris in ira.

ITEM.HI: Hic ecto, -is, vox in aera respon∣dens.

LIST.ITEM:
Hic infernus, -i,
Hic tartarus, -i,
Hic orcus, -i,
Hec jehenna, -e,
Hec avernus, -i, Ance helle.

Hic antepos,
Hec lamea, Ance ffayery.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA DOMORUM.
LIST.ITEM:
Hec eclesia,
Hoc templum,
Hec baselica, Ance a kyrke.

Hoc vestiarium,
Hoc vestibulum, Ance a vestry.

Hoc atrium,
Hec aula, Ance a halle.
Hoc atrium, a kyrkegerde. Atria dic aulas, eadem sumitoria dicas.

Hec camera,
Hec simina,
Hic talamus,
Hec conclavis,
Hec conclave, Ance a schambyr.
Hoc penu, indeclinabile, Ance a seler.

Hec domus,
Hec edes, Ance alle maner of howse.

Hec casa,
Hec casula, Ance a cote.

Hec casula, Ance a schesepylle.
Dico domum parvam casulam tibi dimi∣nutivum,
Ac indumentum dicatur presbeterale.

Hec cansella,
Hoc cansellum, a schanselle.

Hoc penus,
Hoc dispensorium, a spenyse.

Hec coquina,
Hec pompina, a kychon.

Hec tabarna,
Hec caupona,
Hec pila, Ance a taverne.

Hoc granatorium,
Hoc granarium, a garnyr.
Hoc tigurium, Ance a hoywl. A hovel.

Hoc lupaner,
Hec fornix,
Hoc prostibulum, a horehowse.

Hec foruca,
Hec laterrina, a prewy.

Hoc ustrinum,
Hoc torale, a kylinhowse.

Hec scola,
Hoc studium, Ance a scole.

Hoc diversorium,
Hoc hospicium, Ance a hyn.

LIST.HEAD: NOMINA ARTIFICIUM CUM SUIS INSTRUMENTIS.
LIST.ITEM:
Hic cultor,
Hic et hec agricola, a londtyllere.

Hic nauta,
Hic navita, a shypman.
Hec puppis, Ance the in parti. The reading of these words is some∣what doubtful in the manuscript, and I am not sure that I have read them quite correctly.
Hec ratis, Ance the schyppes syde.

Hec carina, Ance a holle.
Prora prior navis pars dicitur, ultima puppis,
Sic latus esse ratem, ventrem dicitur esse carinam.
Hoc naulum, Ance a schyppes tolle.
Hic jaclus, a thred in a nedyl . . .

Hec navicula,
Hec lembus, a bote. Nos vestit limbus, nos vectat per mare lembus.
Hec facelus, Ance a sogbote. Sog-bote. In the Nomenclator, phase∣lus is interpreted as signifying a pinnace.
Hec palmula, the brede of the hore.
Hoc columbar, Ance the holle of the schyp.

FIGURE.FIGDESC: two boats, one with a figure standing in it
FIGURE.HEAD: a navicula

LIST.ITEM: Hoc armamentum, a hal takylle. Haltakylle, I suppose, the whole tackle or furniture of the ship—armamenta navis.

Hic paterfamilias,
Hic maritus, a husbond.

Hic vir,
Hic vel hec homo, a man.
Hic omunculus, Ance a duorow. A dwarf.

Hic servus,
Hic famulus,
Hic verna,
Hic satrapa,
Hoc mancipium, a servante.
Hic vel hec scurra, Ance a harlat.

ITEM.HI: Hic vel hec alocropa, idem est.

LIST.ITEM: Hic nugator, Ance chaper. i. e., a japer, a jester or mocker.
Hic et hec latro, a day-thefe.
Hic fur, Ance a nyte thefe. Tempore nocturno fur aufert, latro diurno
Hic victor, a cummer. Cummer, probably a gossip, Scottice.

LIST.HEAD: CUPERUS CUM SUIS INSTRU∣MENTIS.
LIST.ITEM: Hec acia, a tyxhyl. Tyxhyl, apparently a sort of axe.

Hic bipennus,
Hic bidens, -tis, a stybylle.

FIGURE.FIGDESC: a baker's peel and a basket or barrel?
FIGURE.HEAD: a pila

LIST.HEAD: PANDUCSATOR CUM SUIS INSTRUMENTIS.
LIST.ITEM: Hec cupa, a colle. Colle, a hogshead, or large barrel.
Hec falanga, Ance a try. Try, a corn-screen.

Hoc colum,
Hoc infusorium, Ance tunnyng.

Hoc cinofegium,
Hoc sagisterium, Ance drafe.

LIST.HEAD: PISTOR CUM SUIS INSTRU∣MENTIS.
LIST.ITEM: Hic clibanus, Ance a rele. Rele. Clibanus means properly the oven.

Hoc furnorium,
Hec pila, Ance pyle. The baker's peel, or implement for putting the bread into the oven.

Hoc polen,
Hoc polentum,
Hec simila,
Hoc ador, indeclinabile, Ance flowyr.
Hic panificator, Ance a mouldere. The person who makes the dough into loaves.

Hec costa,
Hoc scalprum, a rybe.
Hec vibra, Ance a brake. One meaning of the word brake is a baker's kneading-trough. It occurs before, p. 807 l. 31, with the same Latin, but evidently in a different sense.
Hec massa, Ance a gobet of dow.
Hic pomelio, custos pomorum. Versus. Pomelio custos, vector, vel venditor extat.
Hec fals, scarpe. Scarpe, an instrument for pruning vines. See the verse in the next column.
Hec labrusca, the bark of the vyne.
Hec antes, a siron. Antes, a sprout.
Hic botrus, a closter. Pampulus est folium, botrus flos, vinea totum.
Hic tector, Ance a thaser. A thatcher.

Hoc sustentaculum,
Hoc podium, a croche.
Hic messor, Ance a scherer. A reaper. Reaping is still called shear∣ing in Scotland.
Hec fals, Ance a sythe. False puto vineta, meto sata, tondeo prata.

Hic auriga,
Hic vereda,
Hic carectarius, a cartar.

Hec biga,
Hoc plaustrum, a wayne.
Hoc carpentum, Ance a schare. i. e., a car.
Hic cantus, -tus, -tui, Ance a song. Cantus, -ti, bige, cantus cantantis in ore.
Hic radius, Ance a sunbeme. Est radius rote, solis, tele, geometrie.
Hec epicia, -orum, Ance a berhom. A barholm, or collar for a horse to draw by.

Hic lucarius,
Hic viridarius,
Hic forestarius, Ance a forster.

Hic nemus, -ris,
Hic lucus,
Hec feresta, a forest.
Hoc vallum, Ance a parke palys.

FIGURE.FIGDESC: a bow and arrow, an arrow

LIST.ITEM:
Hic architenens,
Hic sagittarius, a harchere.
Hec catapulta, Ance a brode arw.
Hec veltria, a lese of grehowndes.
Hoc cornu, indeclinabile, Ance a horne.

Hoc defensorium,
Hoc brachitectum, Ance a braser.
Hec fusticula, Ance a lytyl pype.

Hic archimendritas,
Hic opelio,
Hic pastor, a schepard.

Hic grex,
Hic villus, a flok.

Hoc ovile,
Hec caula, a fold.
Hoc pedum, Ance a scheperdes stafe.
Hic padus, Ance a scheperdes croke.

Hic palus,
Hic paxillus, a foldstake.
Hic edrius, io for a precher.
